In the Sinai desert . . . on the first [day] of the [second] month, etc. °Because they (the Israelites) are precious before Him (Hashem), He counts them all the time; when they went out of Egypt He counted them [Shemos, 12:37], and when they fell because of [the sin of] the golden calf He counted them °to know the number of those who remained, when He came to cause His Presence to rest upon them He counted them. On the first day of Nisan the Mishkon was set up, °and on the first day of Iyar He counted them.
According to their families. To know °the number of each tribe
To the house of their fathers: Someone whose father is from one tribe and his mother from another tribe shall be °maintained in his father’s tribe.
Individually °Through the shekolim a half-shekel per head.
All those eligible for the army. This teaches us that no one is eligible for the army °below the age of twenty.
Along with you, there shall be. °When you count them, there shall be with you the leader of each tribe.
These are the ones called from the congregation. The ones who were invited °to everything of importance in the congregation.
These men. °Those twelve leaders [mentioned above, 5–15].
Who were designated: To him (Moshe) here by [their] names.

And they were registered by family ancestry. They brought their °genealogical documents and witnesses who °verified the status of their birth, this applied to each individual, to establish their kinship with the tribe.

However, the tribe of Levi you shall not count. The King’s legion is worthy of being °counted separately. °Another interpretation; the Holy One, blessed is He, foresaw that a decree would arise against all those who were counted from the age of twenty and above to die in the desert. He [therefore] said, “Let these [Levites] not be included, for they are mine, since they did not sin with the [golden] calf.”

You shall appoint the Levites. As Targum [Onkelos] translates, “appoint.” The word denotes appointment to °authority over the subject of one’s appointment, as, “and let the king appoint officials.” (Esther 2)

[They] shall take it down. °As Targum (Onkelos) translates, “they shall dismantle.” °When they were going to depart in the desert from journey to journey they would dismantle it (the Mishkon) from its upright position and carry it to the place where the cloud came to rest. They camped there and set it up.
And the stranger who approaches: °To [perform] this service of theirs.
Shall die: °By the hand of heaven.
And each man at his own banner. According to the way that the banners are arranged in this book (i.e., Bamidbar, 2:3–31), three tribes to each banner.

So that there will not be anger. If you fulfill My commandments there will not be anger, but if not — if strangers will enter into this service of theirs — °there will be anger, °as we find in the episode of Korach, “. . . for the anger had emerged . . .” [17:11]

With the insignia. Each banner shall have [as] its insignia a colored cloth hanging from it. °Each one’s color was not like the other’s, each color corresponded with the hue of its gem set in the breastplate. Thusly, everyone could recognize his banner. Another interpretation [of] “with the insignia of their fathers’ houses”; By the sign their forefather Yaakov gave them °when they carried him from Egypt [for burial in Canaan], as it is said, “And his sons did to him just as he had commanded them” [Bereishis, 50:12]. ‘Yehudah, Yissachar, and Zevulun shall carry him from the east, Reuven, Shimon, and Gad from the south; etc.,’ as stated by Tanchuma to this portion.

At a distance: °At the distance of a mil (2,000 amos, approximately 4,000 feet.) as stated in the Book of Joshua [3:4], ‘However, there should be a distance between you and it (the sacred ark) of two thousand amos’, To enable them to come on Shabbos. Moshe and Aharon and his sons and the Levites camped near it (the Mishkon).
In the forefront. Toward the side called קֶדֶם, the front. Which is this? °This is the eastern side whereas the west is called אָחוֹר, the rear.

They travel first. °When they see the cloud rise, the kohanim blow the trumpets and the camp of Yehudah departs first. When traveling, they move °the way they camped; The Levites and the wagons at the center, the banner of Yehudah to the east, that of Reuven to the south, Ephraim's to the west, and Don’s to the north.
The Tent of Meeting shall travel. °After those two banners.
Just as they camp, so shall they travel: As I explained, they traveled as they camped, each banner proceeding in its designated position.

In his place [literally “his hand”] In his place. Yet, the literal meaning, “his hand” is not out of context. One’s nearby area is called “at hand,” [i.e.,] adjacent, within hand’s reach. en son aise, at hand, in Old French.
With him [literally “above him”]. °As Targum [Onkelos] translates, “the one near him.”

These are the descendants of Aharon and Moshe. [Scripture] mentions only the sons of Aharon, yet they are called the descendants of Moshe — because he taught them Torah. This teaches us that one who teaches another’s son Torah is considered as having procreated him.
On the day that Adonoy spoke to Moshe They became his descendants, °since he taught them what he had learned from the mouth of the Almighty.
In the presence [literally “the face”] of Aharon. °During his lifetime.

And they shall serve him. What is the service? [The next passage explains —] °”They shall preserve his guardianship;” since he (Aharon) is obligated to guard the Sanctuary so that no stranger may approach, as it is said, “. . . you (Aharon), your sons, and your father’s house with you shall bear [responsibility for] the sin of [defiling] the Sanctuary . . .,” and these Levites aided them, this is the service.

They shall take care to preserve his guardianship. Any position to which a person is appointed which requires his active management is called a “watch” throughout Scripture, and in the Mishnaic idiom, as stated concerning Bigsan and Seresh, “But surely my watch is not similar to yours”? Similarly, the “watches” of the kohanim and Levites.

And the watch of Bnei Yisroel. They were all actually obligated to provide the needs of the Sanctuary; the Levites merely served in their place, as surrogates. This is why they (the Levites) accepted the tithes from them, in payment, as it is said, “. . . for it (the tithe) is your payment, in return for your service . . .”
They are presented to him. °For assistance.

From [among] Bnei Yisroel This [מֵאֵת, “from”] is understood as מִתּוֹךְ, “from among” Bnei Yisroel, meaning °from the rest of the entire congregation they (the Levites) were selected for this by Divine decree and He (God) gave them to him (Aharon), as it is said, “I (God) have given the Levites, given [them] . . .”
Appoint Aharon and his sons. The word connotes appointment, not counting.
And they shall guard their priesthood. Referring to the blood [of the sacrificial offerings], sprinkling [it on the altar], burning [the sacrifices], [and other] services entrusted to the kohanim.

Behold, I have taken [the Levites]. What is My right to them? From among Bnei Yisroel That the Israelites must hire them to serve Me? Through the [Israelites’] first born, I gained my right to them, having taken them (the Levites) in their place. Because the sacred service was [originally performed] by the firstborn, but when they sinned with the golden calf, they were disqualified. The Levites, who did not indulge in idolatry, were chosen instead.

From the age of one month and above. When he (the infant) can no longer be categorized as stillborn, he is listed among those entitled “guardian of the sacred watch.” R’ Yehudah B’rabi Shalom said, “This [Levite] tribe is regularly counted from the womb, as it is said, “. . . [Yocheved, Levi’s daughter] . . . whom she (Levi’s wife) bore to Levi in Egypt . . .” While entering the portals of Egypt, °she bore her (Yocheved). yet she is counted among the seventy souls [who came down to Egypt]. for, when one tallies their total, one finds only sixty-nine and she completed the total.

According to the word of Adonoy. Moshe said before the Holy One, Blessed is He, °”How can I enter into their tents to determine the number of their nursing infants”? The Holy One, Blessed is He, replied, “Do yours, and I will do Mine”! Moshe proceeded, and stood at the door of the tent, whereupon the Divine Presence preceded him [and entered the tent]. A voice then echoed from the tent, announcing, “There are so many and so many nursing infants in this tent”! This is why it is said, “. . . according to the word of God . . .”
Of Gershon, the family of Livni. Meaning, of Gershon, those who were counted [was] °the family of Livni and the family of Shim’i — °their numbers were so many and so many.
The Mishkon. °The lower [ceiling] drapes.
And the Tent. °The goats’ hair drapes, made [to serve] as the roof.
Its Cover. °Ram skins and tachash skins.
And the curtain for the entrance This is °the drape.
And its ropes. °Of the Mishkon and the tent, but not the enclosure.

The families of the children of Kehos shall camp . . . on the south. Near them [was] the banner of Reuven, who camped to the south. °Woe to the wicked, woe to his neighbor! This is why [Reuven’s constituents] were punished — Doson, Avirom, °and two hundred and fifty men — together with Korach and his assembly, because they (the Reuvenites) were drawn, with them, into the dispute.
And the curtain. This is the Paroches, as it was also called “. . . the Paroches screen . . .”
The leader of the leaders of Levi. [He was] °appointed over all of them. Over what was his leadership?
The appointment of the guardians to safeguard — They were all appointed by him.

Moshe, Aharon and his sons. °Near them [was] the banner of the camp of Yehudah, and those who camped near him, Yissachar and Zevulun. Good fortune to the righteous, good fortune to his neighbor! Because they were neighbors of Moshe, who engaged in Torah [study], they became great Torah scholars, as it is said, “Yehudah my lawgiver”; “From the sons of Yissachar of sagacious knowledge, etc.” — [this refers to] two hundred heads of Sanhedrin; “and from Zevulun, came those that handle the scribe’s quill.”
Whom Moshe and Aharon counted. °There are dots over [the word] וְאַהֲרֹן, to teach that he was not included in the counting of the Levites.

Twenty two thousand. When counting them individually, however, one discovers three hundred extra: the sons of Gershon, seven thousand five hundred; the sons of Kehos, eight thousand six hundred; the sons of Merori, six thousand two hundred [hence, twenty two thousand three hundred]. Why aren’t they included among the rest to redeem the firstborn, thus exempting the two hundred seventy three overlapping firstborn from redemption? Our sages answered, in Maseches Bechoros, that the three hundred Levites were, themselves, firstborn. It was sufficient °for them to release themselves from redemption.
Count every male firstborn . . . from the age of one month and above. When he (the infant) can no longer be categorized as stillborn.

And the animals of the Levites . . .etc. The animals of the Levites did not redeem the firstlings of the Israelites’ clean (i.e., kosher) animals, °but [they did redeem] the firstlings of their donkeys. And a single sheep belonging to a Levite released numerous of the Israelites’ donkey firstlings. The proof is that Scripture counts the extra men, °but did not count the extra animals.

And the redemption of the [two hundred and seventy-]three. The firstborn who require redemption among them (the Israelites), these are the two hundred seventy-three extras among them, over and above the Levites. From them, °take five shekolim per head. This was the sale price for Yoseif, twenty silver [pieces], who was Rochel’s firstborn.
[Those whose numbers were] in excess of those who were redeemed through the Levites. Those redeemed by the very presence of the Levites.

One thousand three hundred sixty five. This is the sum total, [at] five shekolim per head. For two hundred firstborn: one thousand shekolim. For seventy firstborn — three hundred and fifty shekolim. For three firstborn — fifteen shekolim. He (Moshe) said, “How shall I do this? Any firstborn whom I tell to pay five shekolim will say, ‘I am from those redeemed by the Levites”’! What did he do? He brought °twenty-two thousand slips and wrote “Levite” on them, and two hundred and seventy three slips and wrote “five shekolim” on them. He mixed them together, and placed them in a container. [Then] he told them, “Come, choose your slips by lot.”

Take the count . . . etc. Count those among them suited °for the service of carrying, the ones from thirty to fifty years of age. Someone younger than thirty, has not reached prime strength. From here they (the Rabbis) derive “[the age of] thirty for strength” and after fifty, one’s strength diminishes.
The Holy of Holies. The Holiest of all; the Ark, the Table, the Menorah, the Altars, the Paroches, and the service vessels.
Aharon and his sons shall enter . . . etc. They shall place each vessel into the sheath specified for it in this chapter, so that the Levite sons of Kehos need do nothing but carry [them].
When the camp is about to travel. °When the cloud rises, they know that they are to depart.
Molds, spoons, rods, covering props. I have explained this in [the chapter dealing with] the work of the Mishkon.
Covering. Covering, from the word מָסָךְ, cover, as it is written, “. . . by which they (the breads) shall be covered.”
Its tongs. A type of pliers with which they pull the wick in any desired direction.
Its scoops. A type of small spoon with a flat, uncurved bottom, unwalled at the front — only at the sides, with which he rakes the ashes from the lamps when cleaning them.
It lamps. Loces, lamps, in Old French, °in which the oil and wicks are placed.
Into the covering of the tachash — hide. A type of °sack.
All the service utensils with which they serve in the Sanctuary. °Inside the Mishkon, which is Holy. These are the incense vessels, with which they serve on the inner altar.
They shall remove the ashes from the Altar. The copper altar.
They shall remove the ashes. °They shall take the ashes away from it.

And spread upon it a cloth of purple [wool]. The fire which descended from heaven lay below the cloth °like a lion when they traveled. It didn’t burn it (the cloth), because they arched a copper °vessel over it.
Firepans. With these they raked the coals for the lifting of the ashes. This was made like a pan with only three sides, and the front was used to draw the coals.
Forks. Copper hooks with which they prodded the limbs on the altar, turning them so that they would be completely consumed quickly.
Scoops. These were scrapers, In Old French, Wadil, scoops. They were made of copper, and used to sweep the ashes from the Altar.
Covering of the Sanctuary. The Ark and the Altar.
And all of the holy utensils. °The Menorah and the service vessels.
And they will [not] die. °Since, if they touch, they will be subject to death by Heavenly decree.

Encharged to Elazar. He was assigned °to carry them; oil, incense, and anointing oil. The continual [daily] meal-offering. His responsibility was to issue orders, to urge [the others], and to offer it [on the altar] when they camped.

The charge of the entire Mishkon. In addition, he was assigned to [oversee] the load of the sons of Kehos — °to issue orders for everyone’s work and load. This is [what is meant by] “the Mishkon and all of its contents,” everything listed above in this chapter. But the load of the sons of Gershon and Merori, which did not consist of the holy of holies, was by order of Isamar, as is written in the portion of נָשׂא .
Do not cut off. °Do not cause them to die.

They shall not come in to see when the holy is being covered. [When placed] into its sheath, as specified above in this chapter, they shall spread over it a certain cloth, they shall cover it with a certain cover. °Its “ בִּלּוּעַ “ refers to the covering of it.
Take the count of the sons of Gershon, as well. °Just as I commanded you conce ning the sons of Kehos, to determine how many °have reached the working category.
The tapestries of the Mishkon. °The ten lower ones.
And the Tent of Meeting. The °goat-hair tapestries, made as a tent over it (the Mishkon).
Its covering. The °red dyed rams’ skins.
The screen for the entrance. °The eastern curtain.
Which are over the Mishkon. As if it had said, “The curtains and screen of the courtyard enclosure which protect and °guard over the Mishkon and °the copper altar on all sides.”
And all that will be given [lit. made] to them. As Targum [Onkelos] translates, °”all that will be given to them” — to the sons of Gershon.
By instruction of Aharon and [one of] his sons. Which of his sons is °appointed over them? Under the supervision of Isamar, son of Aharon, the kohein.

Their stakes and ropes. Of the pillars, since the the stakes and ropes of the curtains were in the load of the sons of Gershon. There were stakes and ropes at the bottom of the tapestries and curtains, so that the wind would not lift them; and there were stakes °and ropes for the pillars, on all sides, from which to hang the curtains, °by their upper border, with bars °and rods, as is taught in [the Beraysa of] the work of the Mishkon.
The service of service. This refers to the song of the cymbals and the harps, which is °service for [another] service.
And the service of carrying. °As the phrase indicates.
And they were counted, as Adonoy commanded Moshe. Those counted were, as commanded, °from the ages of thirty to fifty.
Command Bnei Yisroel. °This parshah was said on the day the Mishkon was erected. Eight parshiyos were said on that day, as is stated in Tractate Gittin, perek Hanizakin.

They must expel from the camp. There were °three camps when they rested: Within the curtains was the camp of the Shechinah; the surrounding Levite encampment, as stated expressly in the parshah of Bemidbar Sinai, was the camp of the Levites; from there to the end of the encampment of the banners, in all the four directions, was the camp of the Israelites. The metzoro was sent °out of all of them. The zav was permitted in the camp of the Israelites, but expelled from the [other] two. A person defiled by the dead was permitted even among the [encampment of] the Levites, being expelled only °from the encampment of the Shechinah. All this, the Rabbis derive from Scriptural passages in Maseches Pesachim.

Defiled by a [departed] soul. [Onkelos renders] דִּמְסָאָב לִטְמֵי נַפְשָׁא דֶאֱנָשָׁא, (“who were defiled by the bones of a human soul.”) In my opinion, the word °means “human bones” in Aramaic. There are many [examples] in Bereishis Rabbah, “ טַמְיָא “ אַדְרִיאָנוּס שְׁחִיק — may [his] “bones” be crushed.

Acting treacherously against Adonoy. Scripture now reiterates the parshah of the thief who swears falsely, previously stated in the Portion of Vayikra, “[If a person sins] . . . and acts treacherously against God, lying to his fellow . . .” It is repeated here for the sake of two innovations. Firstly, Scripture writes “And they confess . . . [their sin],” teaching that he (the thief) is not required to pay the fifth and bring the asham (guilt-offering) when convicted by the testimony of witnesses, unless he confesses to the act. And secondly, [to teach] that property stolen from a proselyte must be given to the kohanim.
Principal amount of his guilt. °This is the principal [payment] concerning which he took the oath.
To whom he is indebted. To the one °to whom he is liable.
But if the man has no redeemer. As the claimant died who put him (the thief) to the oath — without heirs.

To whom the debt may be returned. °When he (the thief) recants and confesses to his crime. The Rabbis remark, ‘Is there anyone in Yisroel without redeemers, whether a son, brother, or paternal blood relation [branching] upward to [the patriarch] Yaakov? But °[this refers to] a proselyte who died without heirs.
The debt being returned. °This is the principal and the fifth thereof.
To Adonoy, [then] to the kohein. God takes possession of it, °then gives it to the kohein [serving] °in that watch.
Besides the ram of forgiveness. °Mentioned in Vayikra, which he is required to bring.

Every terumah-gift, etc. R’ Yishmael said, “Is terumah-gift brought to the kohein? Does he not seek it, himself, in the granary? Then why does the Torah state, ‘ . . . which they bring to the kohein?’ These are the bikurim-gifts, about which it is stated, ‘[. . . the first fruits of your land] must be brought to the House of Adonoy, your God.’ °But one does not know what must be done with them. The Torah therefore states, ‘ . . . to the kohein, it shall belong to him.’ Scripture teaches, concerning the bikurim-gifts, that they must be given to the kohein.

A man’s sacred objects shall be his. Since the priestly and Levite gifts are mandated, one might assume that they may confiscate them forcefully. The Torah therefore teaches that “A man’s sacred objects shall be his,” °informing [us] that the executory benefits belong to the [original Israelite] owner. Many other homiletical interpretations are offered by Sifri. Midrash Aggadah [states], “A man’s sacred objects shall be his” [states]: If someone withholds his tithes, and refuses to give them, [then] “[they shall] be his” — the tithes. Ultimately, his land will yield only one tenth of its normal produce.
Whatever a man gives to the kohein [lit. A man who gives to the kohein]. The proper gifts.
Shall be his. Great riches.

If any man’s wife goes astray. °What is written [immediately] above this subject? “A man’s sacred objects shall be his.” (v. 10) [This implies that] If you withhold the kohein’s gifts, then by your life! You will find it necessary to visit him, to bring the sotah to him.
Any man [lit. A man, a man]. This teaches that she is doubly treacherous; against the “man of warfare” on high, and her husband [lit. “man”] below.

[If any man’s] wife goes astray. Our Rabbis teach: Adulterers do not commit adultery unless they are imbued with the °spirit of foolishness, as it is written כִּי תִשְׂטֶה [lit. acts foolishly]. and it is written, “the adulterer lacks reason”: The simple explanation of the verse is, “[If any man’s wife] °turns aside from the ways of modesty” and arouses his suspicion, as in “turn aside from him, and pass by,” “let your heart not turn to her ways.
And acts treacherously toward him. °What is the treachery?
And a man has lain. This excludes a minor and a non-human.
With her. °Lying with her disqualifies her. but not laying with her sister (as in the incident of two sisters who resembled one another).
But it was hidden from her husband’s eyes. °This excludes a blind man. Therefore, if he (the husband) saw [the adultery] and feigned ignorance, the [bitter] waters do not test her.
She was concealed. °Long enough to have been defiled by intercourse.
There is no witness against her. But if °even one witness testified that she was defiled [by intercourse], she did not drink [the bitter waters].
There is no witness against her. To the defilement, but there are witnesses to the concealment.
Seized forcibly. °Ravished, as in, “. . . siezed her forcibly and laid with her.”
Comes upon him. °Before the concealment.
A spirit of jealousy, and he is jealous. The Rabbis interpret this as “warning.” He warns her not to be alone with a certain man,
And she was defiled. Or, comes upon him . . . etc. As if it had said, ‘he warned her and she ignored the warning, but °it is not known whether or not she was defiled.’
flour. °But not of fine flour.
Barley. But not wheat. [Because] she acted like an animal, her offering consists of animal feed.
He shall not pour oil over it. So that her offering may not be resplendent. for, [olive] oil is °identified as light, while she acted in darkness.
He shall not put frankincense on it. The matriarchs are called “frankincense,” as it is said, “. . . and to the hill of frankincense,” but she departed from their ways.
For it is a meal-offering of jealousy. This meal. “Meal” is masculine.
A meal-offering of jealousy (wrath). She arouses a double wrath against her; the wrath of the Supreme Omnipresent Being, and the wrath of her husband.

Sanctified waters. Sanctified in the wash basin. Because the wash basin was made from the copper of the “multitude mirrors,” while this [sotah] departed from their ways. They had relations with their husbands in Egypt beneath the apple tree, but this [sotah] corrupted herself with a stranger — let her be tested by it (the wash basin).
In a clay utensil. She served the adulterer excellent wine in superb goblets — therefore, let her drink the bitter water in a wretched clay cup.

The kohein shall station . . . etc., Has it not already said, ‘ . .and station her before Adonoy’? (V. 16) °But, they moved her from place to place to exhaust her, so that she might lose her composure and confess.
Expose. °He disentangles the plaits of her hair, to humiliate her. From this we derive that, for daughters of Yisroel, a bared head is °debasing.
Before Adonoy. °At the Nikanor gate. This was the eastern gateway to the [Temple] courtyard, the route by which everyone entered.
And place, on her palms. °To exhaust her, [in the hope] that she might lose her composure and confess, °so that the Sacred Name not be erased in the water.
The bitter. °Because of their aftermath, when they are bitter to her.

Lethal. Which eliminate her from the world, like the phrase, “. . . lethal thornbush.” But it is inappropriate to translate “accursed waters,” as they are sacred [v.17]. And Scripture does not write אֲרוּרִים, but מְאָרְרִים — affecting others. Even Onkelos did not translate לִיטַיָּא, “accursed,” but מְלַטְטַיָּא, “curse causing” — they reveal the curse in the body of this [sotah].

Shall place her under oath . . . etc. What is the oath? °‘If no [man] laid [with you], be absolved but if he laid [with you], may you choke’! A negative statement expresses, by implication, its positive converse, but we are commanded to open capital cases with the presumption of innocence.
If you have gone astray. כִּי is used °in the sense of “if.”
With the oath of accursedness. The oath which contains the curse.
Adonoy shall make you a curse: Everyone will curse through you: ‘May [a curse] befall you °the way it befell so-and-so.’

And an oath. Everyone will swear through you: ‘If [my oath is] not [true], may [disaster] happen to me the way it happened to so-and-so. Similarly, it says, “you will leave your names [to be used] as an oath by My chosen.” — the virtuous swear by the punishment of the wicked. Similarly, with regard to blessings, “and through you will be blessed . . . etc., “through you shall [the People of] Yisroel bless, saying. . .”
Your thigh. In the curse, the thigh precedes the abdomen, because her transgression began there.
Swell. As Targum [Onkelos] translates, “swollen.”

To swell the abdomen. [לַצְבּוֹת בֶּטֶן is] like לְהַצְבּוֹת בֶּטֶן, “to cause the abdomen to swell.” This is the function of the פַּתַּח when it vocalizes the ל' . Similarly, לַנְחוֹתָם הַדֶּרֶךְ, (“to lead them on the way,”) לַרְאוֹתְכֶם בַּדֶּרֶךְ אֲשֶר תֵּלְכוּ בָהּ (“to show you the way in which to go.”) Similarly, לַנְפִּל יָרֵך, לְהַנְפִּיל יָרֵךְ (“to cause the thigh to collapse”). The waters swell the abdomen and collapse the thigh.

To swell the abdomen and collapse the thigh. The abdomen and thigh of the adulterer, or perhaps it refers only to the adulteress? When Scripture says, “. . . your thigh to collapse and abdomen to swell,” the [punishment of the] adulteress has been stated.

Amein, Amein. [This is] The acceptance of the oath. Amein °for the curse, Amein for the oath. Amein if [I strayed] from this husband, Amein if [I strayed] from a different husband. Amein that I did not stray [when] betrothed, married, levirately engaged or taken to his home.

He shall have the woman drink. It was not done in this order, as °he brought her offering first. But Scripture informs you that when he does give her the waters, they will penetrate her with bitterness. °Since it [merely] says “abdomen” and “thigh,” how do we know the rest of the body [is affected]? The Torah states “and [the waters] shall enter her,” completely. If so, why does the Torah say “abdomen” and “thigh”? Since they began the transgression, the punishment began with them.
To become bitter. °They will be harmful and bitter for her.
And shall wave. He moves it forward, back, °up, and down. She, too, waves with him, with her hand °above the hand of the kohein.
And bring it. This refers to placing it at the southwest corner of the altar °before taking the handful, like the other minchah- offerings.
Its commemoration. This is the handful. Through its burning, the mincha-offering is remembered on high. (Sifri, 5:72.)

He shall make her drink the water. [This is written] to add that if she said, °”I will not drink” after the scroll was erased, °we coerce her, forcing her to drink against her will, unless she says “I am defiled.”
Her abdomen will swell. Although, in the curse, Scripture mentions the thigh first, the water °tested her just the way it entered her.
The woman will be a curse. As I explained, everyone will °use her to curse.
Among her people. There is a difference between a person disgraced °among those who know her, and a person disgraced among those who do not know her.
But if the woman was not defiled. °During this concealment.
And is pure. From any other place.

She will be cleansed. Of the lethal waters. °Furthermore, “she will bear seed” — if she suffered during childbirth, her labor will now be painless. If she gave birth to swarthy [babies], they will now be light.
If (lit., or) [he is] a man. As in, “If it was known.” As if it had said, “If he is a vengeful man, and, therefore, he shall have the woman stand.”

The man is cleansed of sin. If the water affected her, let him not be tormented saying: “I was responsible for her death.” He is cleansed from punishment. Another interpretation: After he (the kohein) causes her to drink, she is permitted to be with him (her husband), and he is cleansed of sin. For, °the [untested] sotah is forbidden to [have intimate relations with] her husband.

If . . . sets apart. Sets [himself] apart. Why is the chapter of the nazirite placed next to the chapter of the sotah? To tell you °that whoever observes a sotah °in her decadence should take the nazirite vow against wine, which leads to promiscuity.
A nazirite vow. נְזִירָה always indicates abstinence. Here, too, he abstains from wine.
To set [himself] apart for Adonoy. To separate himself from wine for the sake of heaven.
From new or old [intoxicating] wine. As Targum [Onkelos] translates; “from new wine or old”: °Wine intoxicates when aged.

Anything steeped in grapes. The word [מִשְׁרַת] °denotes adding color to water, or any beverage. In the Mishnaic idiom, there are many [examples]: ‘One does not steep ink or dye’, ‘If a nazirite steeped his bread in wine’.
Seeds. These are the kernels.
Skin. These are the outer shells in which the seeds are [held] °like the tongue of a bell.
He shall be sacred. °His hair, °for growing the growth of hair on his head.

Long. This is vocalized with °a small patach (segol), even though it is attached to “the hair of his head” — the growth of hair. The meaning of פֶּרַע is “growth of hair.” Similarly, “He (the kohein gadol) shall not permit the growth of hair on his head.” It is not considered a פֶּרַע (growth) [if uncut] °less than thirty days.
All the days of his separation, he is sacred. This refers to personal sanctity, °from defilement [by contact] with the dead.
Suddenly. This refers to the unavoidable.
[Or] unexpectedly. This refers to the unintentional. Some say פֶּתַע פִּתְאוֹם is a single statement, [meaning] °”a sudden incident.”
If someone died near him. °In the tent where he was.

On the day of his purification. On the day °when he is sprinkled. Or, perhaps only the eighth [day], when he is completely purified? The Torah therefore states, “on the seventh day.” If the seventh, perhaps even if he was not sprinkled? The Torah therefore states, “on the day of his purification.”

On the eighth day he shall take two turtledoves. This excludes the seventh [day]. Or perhaps it is intended to exclude the ninth [day]? [Scripture] °designated a time for the offerings, and designated a time for those who bring them. Just as the offerings are sanctioned on the eighth, and from the eighth and onward, so [are] those who bring them [sanctioned] on the eighth, and from the eighth and onward.

From his sin [of contact] with a [departed] soul. He was negligent about defilement with the dead. R’ Elazar Hakapar says, [the sin was] that °he inflicted suffering on himself by abstaining from wine.
He shall sanctify his head. By beginning, again, his nazirite counting.
He shall set apart, for Adonoy, his nazarite days. He shall repeat the count of his nazarite days as [counted] originally.
The first days shall elapse. Be discounted.

He shall bring himself [lit. him]. He shall bring himself. This is one of the three usages of אֶת, (literally, “him”), which R’ Yishmael explained this way. Similarly, “They will burden them with sin and guilt. — themselves.” Similarly, “He (Moshe) buried אוֹתוֹ (lit. him) in the valley.” He buried himself.

And their meal-offerings and libations. °Of the burnt-offering and the peace- offering. Because they were included in a group, but then distinguished innovatively, requiring bread, Scripture reinstates them into the group, [stating] that they require libations, following the rule of all burnt and peace-offerings.
Matzoh loaves [mixed with oil] and matzoh wafers. °Ten of each kind.
A peace-offering for Adonoy, along with the basket of matzos. °He shall slaughter the peace-offering with the intent to sanctify the bread.
His meal-offering and libation. °The ram’s.

The Nazir shall shave at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting. Perhaps he shaves in the courtyard? °But this would be grossly disrepectful. Rather, the Nazir shall shave °after the slaughter of the shelamim, concerning which is written “. . . and slaughter, it [the peace-offering] at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.”

Which is under the peace-offering sacrifice. Underneath °the pot in which he cooks it. Because the Nazir’s peace-offerings °were cooked in the courtyard, since the kohein had to remove the foreleg after it was cooked and wave it before God.
The cooked foreleg. °After it was cooked.
It is consecrated to the kohein. °The loaf, wafer, and foreleg are °terumah-gifts to the kohein.

Besides the breast of the wave-offering. °Besides the breast and the shoulder that are due to him from all peace-offerings, there is added to the nazirite peace-offerings, this foreleg. °Because the nazirite peace-offerings were included in a group, but then distinguished innovatively, for the consecration of the foreleg, Scripture must reinstate them into the group and deal, also, with the breast and shoulder.

Aside from what he can afford to bring. If he said, “I am hereby a Nazir with the stipulation to shave [my hair] °relative to a hundred burnt-offerings and a hundred peace-offerings,” [his vow is effective]. According to his vow, that he vows, so shall he fulfill. Added . . . Beyond his nazirite laws. Beyond the nazirite laws. He may °increase, but not reduce. If he said, “I am hereby a nazirite five times [consecutively], with the stipulation to shave [my hair] relative to these three animals,” I do not read, concerning him, “whatever he vows, so shall he do.”
Saying. °Like זָכוֹר, “remembering,” שָׁמוֹר, “keeping.” in Old French, “disant” — gerund.
Saying to them. So that °they all hear.
Saying. [אָמוֹר is] Full. Do not bless them with haste and rushing, but with concentration and a whole heart.
May . . . bless you. May your possessions be blessed.

And protect you. From thieves descending on you for your money. A person who presents a gift to his servant is unable to protect him from everybody, so if bandits descend on him and take it from him, what benefit does he have from the gift? But the Holy One, Blessed is He, is both giver and protector. There are many homiletic interpretations in Sifri.
May Adonoy cause His countenance to shine upon you. May he show you a joyous, radiant countenance.
And favor you. May he grant you favor.
May Adonoy lift his face to you. May he subdue his anger.
They shall bestow My Name. They shall bless them with the explicit Name [of God].
And I will bless them. The Israelites. °I will concur with [the blessing of] the kohanim. Another interpretation [of] °”And I will bless them” — The kohanim.
It came to pass, on the day Moshe finished. The text reads כַּלּוֹת . On the day that the Mishkon was erected, the Israelites were like a כַּלָּה — a bride entering the wedding canopy.

Moshe finished. Bezalel, Aholiav, and all the wise — hearted men constructed the Mishkon, yet Scripture credits it to Moshe, °because he utterly dedicated himself to it, observing the structural design of each object as shown to him on the mountain (Sinai) in order to instruct the artisans, without making a single error in design. We find a similarity with regard to [king] David, because he utterly dedicated himself to the construction of the Beis Ha Mikdash — as it is said: “Remember, Adonoy, unto David all his afflictions; how he swore to Adonoy . . . etc. it was, therefore, called by his name, as it is said: “Observe your House, David.”

[On the day] Moshe finished erecting. It does not say, “On the day [Moshe] erected . . .” This teaches that throughout the seven days of installation Moshe erected and dismantled it, and on that day, he erected it without dismantling it. This is why it says, “On the day Moshe finished erecting” — that day his erecting ended. It was the first of the month of Nisan. °On the second, the [red] cow was burned, on the third, they sprinkled with the first sprinkling, °and on the seventh, [after having been sprinkled again] they were shaven.
They were the leaders of the tribes. °They were officers over them in Egypt, and were beaten because of them, as it is said: “And the officers of the Israelites were beaten, etc.”
They stood by during the counting. They stood with Moshe and Aharon when they counted [Bnei] Yisroel, as it is said, “with you [Moshe and Aharon], shall be. . .”

Six covered wagons. צָב can only mean “covered.” Similarly, “[They will bring your brothers from all the nations . . . with horses and chariots] וּבַצַּבִּים וּבַפְּרָדִים,” “in covered wagons and on mules . . .” Covered wagons are called צַבִּים . [Some interpret צָב in the sense of הַצְבִי יִשְׂרָאֵל, (“The finest in Israel.”) They (the wagons) were fine looking.]

They placed them before the Mishkon. °Because Moshe did not accept [the gift] from their hands until [so] instructed by the omnipresent [God.] R’ Noson said, “Why did the leaders see fit to contribute here at the outset, but for the materials of the Mishkon, they did not contribute at the outset? Because the leaders said as follows: “Let the community contribute as they wish, and any shortfall, we will furnish.” But when they saw that the community had supplied everything, as it is said, “the material was sufficient,” they said, “Now what can we do”? They brought the onyx stones, and the stones set into the ephod and breastplate. This is why they contributed here at the outset.
According to their work. The load of the sons of Gershon was lighter than that of the sons of Merori, who carried the planks, pillars, and sockets.
Because the sacred work was [incumbent] on them. The carrying of sacred objects — the ark, table, etc. Therefore, “they had to carry [them] on their shoulders.”

The leaders brought forward the [offerings for] the consecration of the altar. After they contributed the wagons and cattle to carry the Mishkon, they were ennobled to contribute the offerings for the altar to consecrate it.
The leaders placed their offering before the altar. Because °Moshe did not accept [the gift] from their hands until [so] instructed by the Almighty.

They shall bring forth their offering for the dedication of the altar. But Moshe still did not know how they were to bring the offerings — whether in order of their birth, or in order of the traveling — until the Holy One, Blessed is He, told him that they should bring the offerings according to the traveling, each in his day.
On the first day. That day took ten crowns; [it fell on] the first [day] of creation, first of the leaders, etc., as recorded in Seder Olam.

Of the tribe of Yehudah. Scripture establishes his tribal kinship; °but not that he solicited [payment] from his tribe and then brought [the offering]. But perhaps I should say לְמַטֵּה יְהוּדָה, “for the tribe of Yehudah,” [teaching] that he solicited payment from his tribe and then brought [the offering]? The Torah therefore teaches “this is Nachshon’s offering.” He brought his own.
Both were filled with fine flour. °As a voluntary meal-offering.
[Of] ten gold [shekolim]. As Targum [Onkelos] interprets, °the weight of ten shekolim by the Sanctuary standard was in it.
Filled with incense. °We do not find incense [brought] by an individual, nor [brought] on the outer altar, except for this one alone. This was a temporary injunction.
One [young] bull. °The best of its herd.
One he-goat as a sin-offering. °To atone for [defilement by passing over] the grave of the abyss — [for] indefinite defilement.

Nesanel the son of Tzu’ar brought forward — he brought forward his offering. What does the Torah teach [by saying] “he brought forward” with respect to the tribe of Yissachar, without having said it with respect to all the [other] tribes? Because Reuven came with a complaint, saying ‘Enough that Yehudah preceded me! Let me bring my offering after him.’ Moshe said to him, By the Almighty ‘It was told to me that they should bring the offerings in the order of the journeys, according to their banners.’ This is why it says אֶת קָרְבָּנוֹ “ הִקְרִב,” without the “yud,” inferring הַקְרֵב, “you shall bring forward!” — the imperative usage, since Moshe was commanded by the Almighty, “ הַקְרֵב .” What is [the inference of] “[Nesanel] brought forward,” [“he brought forward”] twice? Because there were two reasons by which he merited bringing his offering second among the tribes. One, because of their (his tribe’s) knowledge of Torah, as it is said, “From the sons of Yissachar, of sagacious, timely knowledge.” And one, because they advised the leaders to donate these offerings. In R’ Moshe Hadarshan’s commentary I found: “R’ Pinchos ben Yair said: ‘Nesanel the son of Tzu'ar offered this advice.”’
Silver tray. Its letters are numerically equivalent to °930, corresponding to the years of Adam.

Its weight was one hundred thirty [shekolim]. Alluding that when he (Adam) fathered progeny to sustain the world, he was one hundred thirty years old, as it is said: “Adam lived one hundred thirty years, and fathered . . . etc.”

One silver bowl. The numerical value is 520, alluding to Noach, who fathered his progeny at the age of 500, and alluding to the 20 years by which the decree for the flood preceded his progeny, as I explained [the verse] “His days shall be a hundred and twenty years.” This is why it says מִזְרָק אֶחָד כֶּסֶף, but does not say מִזְרַק כֶּסֶף אֶחָד, as it says concerning the tray — to teach that the letters of אֶחָד are also included in the calculation.
Seventy shekolim. Corresponding to the 70 nations which emerged from his (Noach’s) sons.
One spoon (lit. hand). Corresponding to the Torah, which was given from the hand of the Holy One, Blessed is He.
Ten gold [shekolim]. Corresponding to the ten commandments.
Filled with incense. The numerical value of קְטֹרֶת, is 613, corresponding to the 613 commandments — provided you convert the קו"ף into a דל"ת, by using א"ת ב"ש ג"ר ד"ק .
One [young] bull. Corresponding to Avraham, concerning whom it is said: “He took a young bull.”
One ram. Corresponding to Yitzchok, “He took the ram.”
One [yearling] sheep. Corresponding to Yaakov: “Yaakov separated the sheep.”
Goat. To atone for the sale of Yoseif, concerning whom it is said: “They slaughtered a goat.”
For the peace-offering sacrifice, two oxen. Corresponding to Moshe and Aharon, who made peace between the Israelites and their Father in heaven.

Rams, goats, sheep. Three species, corresponding to kohanim, Levites and Israelites, and corresponding to the Torah, the Prophets, and the Sacred Scripture. Three fives, corresponding to the five chumashim [of the Torah], to the five commandments written on the one tablet, and five commandments written on the other. Until here, [my remarks are] from the commentary of R’ Moshe Hadarshan.

On the third day, the leader etc. °On the third day, the leader who brought the offering was from the sons of Zevulun, and so with all of them. But with Nesanel, concerning whom it is said, “Nesanel brought forth,” the proper succeeding words are “leader of Yissachar,” since it has already mentioned his name and that he brought. With the others, about whom it does not say “he brought,” the proper words are these: “the leader of the children of so-and-so,” that day, the leader who brought was from the tribe of so-and-so.

On the day it was anointed. On the very day it was anointed, he (each leader) brought the offering. Then how do I justify “after it was anointed”? [To teach] That it was anointed first, and then he brought the offering. But, perhaps “after it was anointed” [means] after a time, and “on the day it was anointed” merely teaches that it was anointed by day? When it says “on the day they were anointed,” we learn that it was anointed by day. Then why does the Torah write “on the day it was anointed”? °On the day it was anointed, he brought the offering.
Twelve silver trays. °These were the very ones that were donated, none were disqualified.

One hundred thirty [shekolim was the weight of] each tray. Why does the Torah say this? Because it said “one hundred thirty [shekolim was] its weight,” but does not explain °by which shekel standard. Therefore, Scripture repeats it here, and includes everything — “all the silver of the vessels” — in the shekel of the sacred standard.
All the silver vessels, etc. This teaches you that the Sanctuary vessels were weighed with °precision. Whether weighed individually or collectively, there was neither excess nor shortfall.

Twelve golden spoons. Why is this said? Because it says, “one spoon of ten gold,” [meaning] °it was golden, and it weighed ten silver shekolim. But perhaps [it means] one silver spoon, weighing ten golden shekolim — and the golden shekolim are not the same weight as the silver ones? — The Torah therefore writes “golden spoons” — they (the spoons) were gold.

When Moshe would enter. When two passages conflict, a third decides between them. One passage says: “God spoke to him from the Tent of Meeting” — this was outside the paroches partition. And one passage says: “I will speak to you from above the cover [of the Ark].” This [passage] comes and decides between them. Moshe came to the Tent of Meeting. There he heard the Voice coming from above the cover. Between the two cherubs. The Voice emanated from heaven to the space between the two cherubs, and from there to the Tent of Meeting.

He would hear the Voice. Perhaps the Voice was low (of a lesser degree)? The Torah therefore writes אֶת הַקּוֹל, “the Voice” — the Voice spoken to him at Sinai. But when it reached the doorway, it ceased, and did not go out of the tent.
Being spoken. As being spoken unto Itself. It is respectful to the One above to speak thusly. He was speaking to Himself, and Moshe was listening in.
He spoke to him. This excludes Aharon from the communications.

When you light. Why is the parshah of the Menorah adjacent to the parshah of the leaders? Because when Aharon saw the leaders’ dedication (offerings) he was humiliated, since he did not join them in the dedication, neither he nor his tribe. The Holy One, Blessed is He, said to him, “By your life, yours is greater than theirs! For you will light and cleanse the lamps.”

When you light (lit. cause to rise). °Because the flame rises, igniting is described in terms of “rising.” He is required to ignite [the lamp] until the flame rises by itself. In addition, the Rabbis derive from here °that there was a platform before the Menorah, °upon which the kohein stood when he lit [the lamps].
Toward the face of the Menorah. Toward the middle lamp which was not on one of the branches, but on the Menorah itself.

Shall the seven lamps cast [their] light. The six [lamps] that were on the six branches [and one on its stem]. The three eastern ones turned toward the middle [by] °their wicks. Similarly, the three western ones — the heads of their wicks [were] towards the middle. Why? So that it whould not be said that He (God) needs the light.
Aharon did so. °To indicate his [Aharon’s] virtue — he did not digress.

This is how the Menorah was made. The Holy One, Blessed is He, showed him (Moshe) by pointing [as one would point] with the finger, °since he had difficulty with it. This is why it says וְזֶה (“This”).

Beaten. Batedic (hammered) in Old French, meaning the same as דָּא לְדָא נָקְשָׁן, (“they struck one another”). There was a °lump of gold, [weighing] a kikar, [which] he beat with a hammer and cut with °shears to extend its (the Menorah’s) limbs properly; but it was not made limb by limb and [then] connected.
From its base until its flowers. Its base was the hollow box over the legs, hollowed like the silver candelabras before princes.
From its base until its flowers. As if to say, °”The Menorah proper, in its entirety, and all its dependent parts.”
From its base. Which was a large limb.

Until its flowers. Its most °delicate work — it was all one piece. עַד (“until”), is customarily used in this sense, like “From the harvested crop, until the standing grain, and until the olive grove.”
According to the vision which [Adonoy] showed . . . °According to the form which He showed him on the mountain (Sinai), as it is said: “Observe and make them according to the form. . .etc.”
So he made the Menorah. °The one who made it. But Midrash Aggadah [states] by the Holy One, Blessed is He, °it was made spontaneously.
Take the Levites. °Take them with words of persuasion, “you are fortunate to merit becoming servants of the Omnipresent.”
Sprinkle them with the sin-offering waters. Of the ashes of the red cow, °for some of them were defiled by contact with the dead.

And cause a razor to pass. I found in R’ Moshe Hadarshan’s remarks: “Because they were given in atonement for the firstborn °who practiced idolatry, which is referred to as ‘sacrificing to the dead,’ and since the leper is considered dead, they required shaving like lepers.”
They should take a young bullock. This was a burnt-offering, as it is written, “he should make . . . one a burnt-offering.” This is the communal sacrifice for idolatry.

And a second bullock. °What does the Torah teach [by specifying] ‘a second’? To inform you that, just as the burnt-offering was not eaten, so was the sin-offering not eaten. °This supports his remarks, from Toras Kohanim. Now I say °that it was a temporary ruling, as they should have brought a goat as a sin-offering for idolatry with the burnt-offering bull.
And you shall gather the entire congregation Since the Levites are given as an atonement-offering in their place, let them come °and stand near their offering and rest their hands on them.

Aharon shall wave the Levites as a wave-offering Just as the leper’s guilt- offering °requires waving when it is still alive. °Three wavings were stated in this chapter: The first, of the sons of Kehos. Therefore it is stated of them: “They will be [entrusted] to do the worship of Adonoy,” since the work of the holiest is upon them — the Ark and the Table etc. The second, of the sons of Gershon. It is therefore stated of them: “A wave-offering to Adonoy,” for even they were entrusted with holy work — tapestries and the hooks which were seen in the Holy of Holies. And the third, of the sons of Merori.
They are given; they are given. Given for carrying, given for singing.
פִּטְרַת The opening of.

For every first born is Mine. The first born were Mine by the rules of justice, °since I protected them among the Egyptian firstborn. So I took them for Myself — until they strayed with the [golden] calf. Now I have taken the Levites.

I have given the Levites, etc. °Bnei Yisroel are mentioned five times, in this passage, to make their preciousness known. They are remembered repeatedly in a single passage to correspond with the number of the five books of the Torah. I saw this in Bereishis Rabbah.
So that there will not be a plague among Bnei Yisroel. So that they will not need °to approach the Holy, for if they approach, there will be a plague.
Moshe, Aharon, and the entire congregation did, etc. Moshe placed them, Aharon waved them, and °the Israelites rested their hands.
Just as Adonoy commanded, etc. so they did. This indicates the praiseworthiness of those who did, and those with whom it was done — °no one objected.
This concerns the Levites. Age disqualifies them, but physical deformity does not disqualify them.

From the age of twenty-five. But elsewhere it says, “From the age of thirty.” How is this reconciled? From the age of twenty-five he begins to study of the laws of the service. He studies for five years, and serves at the age of thirty. From here [we derive] that a pupil who does not see °favorable indications in his studies for five years will never see (them).

And shall no longer work. At the task of carrying °on the shoulder, but he returns to lock the gates, to sing, and to load the wagons. This is [the meaning of] “But he shall serve his brethren,” ‘with his brethren’, as Targum [Onkelos] renders.
To keep the watch. To camp around the Tent, and erect and dismantle [it] during the journeys.

In the first month. The chapter at the beginning of this book °was not said until Iyar. You learn, that there is no order of precedence or succession in the Torah. But why did He not begin with this [chapter]? Because it is to Yisroel’s discredit, °that throughout the forty years that Yisroel was in the wilderness they offered no other Pesach-offering but this.
In its proper time. Even on Shabbos; °even during ritual uncleanliness.
According to all its statutes. These are the commandments pertaining to its body [i.e., the animal itself] a lamb; unblemished; male; a yearling.

And according to all its laws. °These are commandments having a bearing on the animal but originate from another place (i.e., outside the animal) For example, the seven days of eating matzoh and of eliminating chometz. ([An alternate text:] The commandments pertaining to its body — a lamb; unblemished; male; a yearling. Having a bearing on the animal; roasted over fire, its head with its knees and its inner organs. Outside its body — matzoh and eliminating chometz.)

Moshe spoke, etc. What does the Torah teach? Does it not say, “Moshe spoke °of God’s holidays”? Evidently, when he heard the parshah of the holidays at Sinai, he told it to them, and then he reviewed it and exhorted them at the time it was to be performed.

Before Moshe and before Aharon. When both were seated in the study hall, they approached them and asked. But it is untenable to say [that they asked them] one after the other, for if Moshe did not know, how would Aharon [know]?

Why should we be excluded. °He (Moshe) said to them: “The sacred offerings cannot be brought during ritual impurity.” They said to him: “[But] let the blood be sprinkled on us by ritually pure kohanim and the flesh eaten by those who are pure.” He said to them: “Wait, while I listen,” like a disciple assured of hearing from his master’s mouth. Fortunate is the mortal thus assured, for whenever he wished, he could speak with the Divine Presence. Now °this chapter should appropriately have been said through Moshe, as is all the rest of the Torah. But these [people] gained the merit of having it said through them, because Providence brings about merit through the meritorious.

Or on a distant road. There is a dot over this, as if to say: Not that it was definitely distant, °but that he was outside the threshold of the [Temple] courtyard thoughout the time for slaughtering [the Pesach]. [At] the second Pesach, °matzoh and chometz may be with him at home; it is not considered ‘yom tov’; and chometz is not prohibited except while he eats [the korbon].

If a proselyte dwells among you, and brings the Pesach-offering. Perhaps everyone who converts must immediately bring the Pesach-offering? The Torah therefore teaches, “One statute, etc . . .” Rather, this is its meaning: “If a proselyte dwells among you, and he comes to bring the Pesach-offering with his fellows, according to the statutes of the Pesach-offering and its laws shall he do.”
The Mishkon [which served] as the Tent of Testimony. °The Mishkon which was made to be a tent for the tablets of testimony.
There was over the Mishkon. Similar to, “would constantly be” over the Mishkon. °Similarly, all the usages in the parshah.

The Cloud was lifted. As Targum [Onkelos] renders, אִסְתַּלָּקוּת, (“was lifted”). Similarly, “the Cloud °was lifted.” But it would be improper to write “According to when the Cloud rose,” “the Cloud rose,” because the connotation is not rising, but flowering and ascending, as in, “behold, a tiny cloud, like a man’s palm, rises from the sea.”

On the word of Adonoy did they travel. We learned in [the Beraysa describing] the work of the Mishkon; When the Israelites were departing the Cloud column would fold, and extend over the tribe of Yehudah like a type of beam. They sounded the tekiah, teruah, and tekiah. But it did not proceed until Moshe intoned, “Rise, Adonoy . . .” Then the banner of the camp of Yehudah departed. °This is in Sifri.

On the word of Adonoy did they camp. When the Israelites were camping, the Cloud column would mushroom upward and extend over the tribe of Yehudah like a type of protective covering. It did not separate until Moshe said, “Come to rest, Adonoy, among the myriads and thousands of Israel.” Thus you say, “on the order of Adonoy, through Moshe.”
Sometimes (lit. there is). As if to say, “sometimes.”
A number of days. “a few days.”
Or a year. (lit. days). A year, °as in “[יָמִים], a year shall be its redemption [period].”
(Make for yourself. So that they they may sound the trumpet before you like a king, as it is said, “There was a king among the righteous.”
Make for yourself. From your own resources.
Make for yourself. You shall make them and use them, but no one else.)
To summon the congregation. When you want to speak with the Sanhedrin or the rest of the people, and you summon them to gather before you, summon them with the trumpets.

And to initiate the departure of the camps. °At the time of the camps’ departure, sound them as a signal. Consequently, you say that they departed on the basis of three [initiatives]. By the word of the Holy One, Blessed is He; by the word of Moshe; and by the trumpets.
Beaten. From a [single] ingot you should make it, by beating [it] with a hammer.
When they will blow them. Both of them. This is the signal for summoning the community, as it is said, “The entire community shall present itself to you at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.”

But if they blow one of them. This is the signal for summoning the leaders, as it is said, “The leaders shall present themselves to you.” °They, too, meet at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting. °This is derived by Scriptural comparison in Sifri.
When you blow a teruah. The signal for the camps to depart; °tekiah, teruah tekiah. This is how it is extrapolated by Sifri from the redundant passages.

But when gathering the congregation, etc. °Since it says, “they shall be used by you, to summon the congregation and to initiate departure of the camps” — [we derive that] just as, when summoning the community, the trumpeting is by two kohanim with both [trumpets], as it is said, “they shall trumpet with them, etc . . .” so, when initiating the camps’ departure, with both. °Perhaps, just as, when initiating the camps’ departure, they sound the tekiah, teruah, and tekiah, so, too, when summoning the community, they sound the tekiah, teruah, and tekiah, thus leaving no differentiation between summoning the community and initiating the camps’ departure? The Torah therefore teaches, “But when gathering the congregation, etc. . .” to say that there is no teruah for gathering the community. The same rule applies for the leaders. Here is a synopsis for all three: summoning the community with two, that of the leaders with one. Each of these has no teruah. Initiating the camps’ departure with two, through the teruah and tekiah.
The sons of Aharon . . . shall sound. For those summonings and departures.
For your burnt — offerings. Scripture speaks °of the communal offerings.

I am Adonoy your God. From here we learn [that we combine Adonoy’s] Majesty, remembrance, and the shofar, as it is said, °”You shall blow” — hence the shofar, “as a remembrance” — this is remembrance, “I am Adonoy your God” — this is Majesty, etc.

In the second month. Thus you say that they spent °twelve months minus ten days at Chorev, since on the first of the month of Sivan they encamped there and did not depart until the twentieth of Iyar the following year.
On their journeys. According to the rules specified for the journeying of their banners — who was first, and who last.
In the desert of Paran. °Kivros Hata’avoh was in the desert of Paran. That is where they camped °after this journey.

The Mishkon was dismantled. When the banner of Yehudah was departing, Aharon and his sons entered, dismantled the paroches, and covered the Ark with it, as it says, “Aharon and his sons shall enter when the camp is about to travel.” The sons of Gershon and the sons of Merori dismantled the Mishkon and loaded it onto the wagons [and traveled]. The Ark and the sacred vessels carried by the sons of Kehos remain covered, placed on poles, until the banner of the camp of Reuven departed. Afterward, “The Kehos family traveled.”
Carriers of the sacred. Carriers of the sacred objects.

They erected the Mishkon. The sons of Gershon and the sons of Merori, °who were preceded by °the departure of two banners, would erect the Mishkon when the Cloud rested. The signal for making camp was observed by the banner of the camp of Yehudah. They camped while the sons of Kehos still traveled behind with the two final banners. The sons of Gershon and the sons of Merori would erect the Sanctuary, so that when the sons of Kehos arrived, they found it set in place, and brought in the Ark, Table, Menorah, and Altars. This is the sense of the passage: “They — the Mishkon’s erectors — erected it before the arrival of the sons of Kehos.”

The gatherer for all the camps. Talmud Yerushalmi [teaches]: Because the tribe of Don was heavily populated, they traveled last. If anyone lost property, it would return it to them. There is an opinion that °they traveled in the shape of a box, derived from, “Just as they camped, so they traveled.” °Another opinion is that they traveled in the shape of a beam, derived from “The gatherer for all the camps.”
These are the journeys. °This is the order of their journeys.
They journeyed. °On that day, they journeyed.

Chovav. °This was Yisro, as it is said, “Of the children of Chovav, the father-in-law of Moshe.” Then why does the Torah say, “They came to their father, Reuel”? This teaches that children call their grandfather “father.” He had many names. “Yisro” [lit. “additional”] because he added a chapter to the Torah; “Chovav” [lit. “one who cherishes”] because he cherished the Torah, etc . . .

We are journeying to the place. Immediately. °Within three days, we enter the [holy] land. Because at this first journey, they traveled with the intention of entering Eretz Yisroel, but they sinned with the complainers. But why did Moshe include himself with them? Because the decree was not yet issued against him, °and he thought he would enter.
To my land and to my birthplace. °Whether for the sake of my properties, or for the sake of my family.

Please do not forsake. נָא is a term indicating nothing but request, °so that they will not say Yisro did not convert out of devotion. He thought that proselytes receive a portion of the land [but] now that he saw that they do not receive a portion, he left them and went on his way.
For, because you know of our encampment in the desert. For it is appropriate for you to do this, because you know of our encampment in the desert, and you saw the miracles and mightiness done for us.

For, because you know. Like עַל אֲשֶׁר יָדַעְתָּ, “because” you know, as in כִּי עַל כֵּן, for, “because” I did not give her to my son Shelah, כִּי עַל כֵּן, for, “because” you passed by, כִּי עַל כֵּן, for, “because” they came, כִּי עַל כֵּן, for, “because” I saw your face.

You will be our eyes. °Past tense, as Targum [Onkelos] renders. Another interpretation: °Future tense. [Should] anything [be] concealed from our eyes, you shall enlighten our eyes. Another interpretation: You shall be as precious to us as the pupils of our eyes, as it is said, “You shall love the proselyte.”

It shall be that the very good (lit. that good). What good did they bestow upon him? They said: “When the Israelites divided the land there was °a fertile area of Yericho, five hundred amos by five hundred amos, which they left undivided.” They said: “The one in whose portion the Temple would be built would take it.” In the interim, they gave it to the children of Yisro, to Yonadav, the son of Rechav, as it is said, “The sons of Keini, Moshe’s father-in-law, went up from the city of the dates, etc . . .”
A journey of three days. Three days’ traveling distance, °they traveled in one day, because the Holy One, Blessed is He, wanted to bring them into the land immediately.

The Ark of the Covenant of Adonoy traveled in front of them a journey of three days. This was the Ark which °went with them to war, in which the broken Tablets were placed. It preceded them by three days’ travel to prepare a camping place for them.

The Cloud of Adonoy was above them. °Seven Clouds are recorded during their journeys; Four on four sides, one above, one below, and one preceding them, to lower the highlands, raise the lowlands, and to kill snakes and scorpions.
From the camp. From their camping place.

Whenever the Ark departed. Scripture placed symbols before and after this [chapter] to teach °that this is not its place. Why, then, was it written here? In order to intervene °between one punishment and the next . . . etc., as stated in “all the sacred scriptures.”
Rise, Adonoy. Because He (Adonoy) preceded them by three days’ travel, Moshe would say, ‘Rise and wait for us, do not go further away.’ Midrash Tanchuma, Vayakhel.
May Your enemies disperse. °Those gathered together.
Those who hate You flee. These are the pursuers.

Those who hate You. °These are the haters of Yisroel, since all those who hate Yisroel hate the One who spoke, and the world came into being, as it is said, “those who hate You have raised [their] heads” — who are they? — “Against Your people they counsel cunningly.”
Come to rest, Adonoy. Menachem interprets this as a term meaning rest. Similarly, “with rest and calm you will be saved.”
[Among] the myriads and thousands of Israel. This informs us that the Divine Presence does not rest among the Israelites when there are fewer than °twenty-two thousand.

The people were like complainers. °”The people” refers only to the wicked. Similarly, it says, “what shall I do for this people,” and it says, “this evil people.” But when they are °righteous, they are called “My people,” as it says, “send out My people,” “My people, what have I done to you”

Like complainers. מִתְאֹנְנִים is strictly a term referring to a pretext. They seek a pretext in order to turn away from [following] after the Omnipresent. Similarly, it says about Shimshon, “for he seeks a pretext.”

Wicked in the ears of Adonoy. A complaint which is wicked in the ears of God, for they intended it to reach His ears and anger Him. They said, “Woe to us, °how we have toiled on this journey. Three days [have passed] that we have not rested from the fatigue of travel.”
And His anger flared. I meant for your benefit, so that you would enter the land immediately.
The outcasts of the camp. Those among them who were outcasts, of low status, they were the great mixture. R’ Shimon ben Menasya says, °the distinguished among them, and the great ones.

The people cried out to Moshe. This is °compared to a mortal king who was angry with his son. The son went to his father’s intimate friend, and said to him, ‘Go, ask [for forgiveness] for me from father.’
And the fire subsided. It subsided °into its place, for if it had turned to any one direction, it would have gathered itself and proceeded in that entire direction.
The collection [of nationalities]. These were [members of] the “great mixture” which gathered with them when they left Egypt.
And [Bnei Yisroel] turned. Bnei Yisroel, also, °and wept with them.

Who will feed us meat? Did they not have meat? Did it not say previously, “A great mixture also went up with them, with sheep and cattle, etc.”? Perhaps you will say they ate them, but does it not say, when they came into the land, “Much cattle belonged to the sons of Reuven, etc.” Evidently, they sought a pretext.

Which we ate in Egypt freely. Perhaps you will say that the Egyptians °gave them fish freely. But did it not already say, “straw will not be given to you”? If they did not give them straw freely, would they have given them fish freely? Then what is meant by “freely”? °Free of mitzvos.

The cucumbers. R’ Shimon said: Why was the manna transformed into everything but these? Because they are harmful to nursing mothers. We tell a woman: “Do not eat garlic or onion for the baby’s sake.” This is compared to a king, etc., as stated by Sifri.
The cucumbers. They are “cocombres” in Old French.
Melons. “Borekes” [in Old French].
The leeks. Leeks, “porels” [in Old French]. (Targum [Onkelos] renders “the leeks, etc.”)
The manna before our eyes. Manna in the morning, manna in the evening.

The manna is like coriander seed. The one who said this [verse] did not say the other. The Israelites said, ‘Nothing but the manna before our eyes.’ while the Holy One, Blessed is He, inscribed in the Torah, “But the manna was like coriander seed, etc.,” as if to say, ‘Look, those who walk the earth at the subject of My children’s complaint — the manna was precious for such and such a reason’.
Like coriander seed. °Round like coriander. “Aliendre” seed in Old French.
Crystal The name of a precious stone, “cristal” [in Old French].
Strolled about. שִׁיוּט is interpreted strictly as strolling, “esbaneier” [in Old French], without exertion.
They ground [it] with a millstone, etc. It never descended into the millstone, or the pot, or the mortar; °rather, its taste changed to ground, crushed, or cooked [foods].
בַּפָּרוּר . Pot.

לְשַׁד הַשָׁמֶן . The moisture of oil. This is how Donash explained it. Similar to this, “ לְשַׁדִּי was overturned by the heat of summer.” °The “lamed” is part of the root, “My moisture was overturned by the heat of summer.” The Rabbis, however, explain it as a term meaning שָׁדַיִם, “breasts.” But שָׁדַיִם have no relation to oil. One cannot say that לְשַׁד הַשָׁמֶן is translated like וַיִשְׁמַן יְשׁוּרוּן, “The righteous were fattened,” for, if so, the “ מ “ would be vocalized with a minor “kametz” (“tzeirei”) and the emphasis below, under the “ מ .” Now that the “ מ “ is vocalized with a minor “patach” (“segol”) and the emphasis is below the “ ש,” it is translated as “oil.” The “ ש “ is vocalized with a major “kametz” (”kametz”), but not with a minor “patach” (”segol”), because it closes the passge. Another interpretation: לְשַׁד is an acronym, [spelling] לִ'ישׁ, שֶׁ'מֶן, דְּ'בַשׁ, °kneaded, oil, honey. [It was] like a loaf kneaded with oil and coated with honey. Onkelos’ translation, rendered “kneaded with oil,” °leans toward Donash’s interpretation, since a loaf kneaded with oil contains the moisture of oil.

Weep according to their families. Every family gathered together and wept, to publicize their complaints openly. The Rabbis remark that לְמִשְׁפְּחוֹתָיו means “concerning family matters” — concerning °the intimate relations forbidden to them.

That You say [lit. will say]. °That You say to me, ‘carry it in your lap.’ Where did He say this to him? “Go, lead the people.” And it says, “He commanded them (Moshe and Aharon) to [lead] Bnei Yisroel” [even] on condition °that they stone you and insult you.
To the land which You swore to their forefathers. You tell me °to carry them in my lap.

If this is the way You treat me. Moshe’s strength weakened °like a female’s when the Holy One, Blessed is He, showed him the punishment He would visit upon them for this. He said before Him: ‘If so, kill me first.’

So that I will not see my evil. It should have written “their evil,” but Scripture euphemizes. This is °one of the “scribes’ adjustments” to the Torah, for the sake of euphemistic language adjustment.

Gather for Me. Here is °the reply to your complaint when you said, “I am unable, alone . . .” But where were the original elders? Had they not sat with them even in Egypt, as it says: “Go, gather the elders of Israel”? Evidently, they died at the fire of “Tav’erah.” They deserved this at Sinai, as it is written, “they gazed at God.” Because they acted frivolously, °like someone munching his loaf while speaking before the king. And this is [the meaning of] “They ate and drank.” But the Holy One, Blessed is He, did not want to cause grief during the giving of the Torah, so he punished them here.

Whom you know to be, etc. Those whom you recognize, as they were appointed °officers over them in Egypt for the body breaking labor. They took pity on them, and were beaten for their sake, as it says, “The Israelite officers were beaten.” Let them be appointed now, in their greatness, just as they suffered when they were oppressed.
You shall take them. Take them verbally. “How fortunate you are to have been appointed as leaders over the Omnipresent’s children.”

And they shall stand there with you. So that the Israelites will see, and treat them as great men, reverently, saying: ‘How precious are those who entered with Moshe to hear the word from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed is He.’
I will descend. This is °one of the ten descents inscribed in the Torah.
And I will speak with you. But not with them.
I will make greater. As Targum [Onkelos] renders, וַאֲרַבֵּי, °”I will make greater,” like, “But to the great men of Bnei Yisroel.”
And place it on them. To what was Moshe compared at that time? To a lamp set in a candelabra. Everyone lights from it, but none of its own brightness is diminished.
They will bear, along with you. Stipulate with them, on condition that they accept upon themselves the toil of my children, as they are troublesome and recalcitrant.
So that you need not bear it alone. Here is the reply to your statement, “I am unable, alone . . .”
Prepare yourselves. °Prepare yourselves for punishment. Similarly, it says, “Prepare them for the day of killing.”

For a month of days. °This was with the [comparatively] virtuous ones, who fell ill in their beds and afterwards expired. But with the wicked ones it says, “the meat was still between their teeth.” This is how it is taught by Sifri. Mechilta, however, teaches the reverse. The wicked ones ate and suffered for thirty days, but with the decent ones — the meat was still between their teeth.
Until it comes out of your nostrils. As Targum [Onkelos] translates, °”you are disgusted by it.” It will seem to you as if you gorged on it until it is expelled through the nose.
It will be repulsive to you. You will cast it away °more readily than you welcomed. In R’ Moshe Hadarshan’s commentary I saw that, in a certain language, the sword is called “zara.”
Adonoy Who is among you. If I had not planted My Presence among you, °you would not have had the arrogance to enter into all these affairs.
Six hundred thousand on foot. He was not concerned with counting in detail the remaining three thousand. R’ Moshe Hadarshan explains that only °those who went out of Egypt, wept.

Will sheep and cattle be slaughtered. This is one of four instances expounded upon by R’ Akiva, which R’ Shimon did not expound as he did. R’ Akiva said, “Six hundred thousand on foot, etc. and You say ‘I will give them meat to eat for a month of days’? Will sheep and cattle . . . ?” Everything according to the straightforward interpretation, who will satisfy them? This is similar to what is said, “And he has sufficient means for its redemption.” °Now which is worse, this, or, “listen, here, rebels!”? Yet, since he did not say it publicly, Scripture spared him and did not punish him; but the one during the dispute was public — Scripture, therefore, did not spare him. R’ Shimon said, Heaven forbid! Such a thought never occurred to that righteous man. Someone of whom it is written, “In all My houshold he is [most] faithful” would say, ‘The Omnipresent cannot satisfy us’? Rather, this is what he said: Six hundred thousand on foot, etc., and You said, ‘I will give them meat for a month,’ and then you will kill a nation as great as this? Will sheep and cattle be slaughered for them so that they should be killed, and this meal will [thus] satisfy them forever? Does this bring you praise, telling a donkey, ‘Eat a ton of barley and then we will chop your head off’? The Holy One, Blessed is He, answered him: But if I do not give it to them, they will say My power [lit. hand] is limited. Is it favorable, in your eyes, that God’s power be limited in their eyes? Let them, and a hundred like them, perish, but My power cannot seem limited to them even for a moment.

Now you will see if My words will occur. Raban Gamliel, son of R’ Yehudah Hanasi said: (Moshe said:) “It is impossible to maintain one’s position °in [such] a dispute. Since they only seek a pretext, You cannot satisfy them, in the end they will judge You critically. If You give them beef, they will say ‘we wanted mutton,’ if You give them mutton, they will say ‘we wanted beef, we wanted wild game or fowl, we wanted fish or locusts.’ He (God) said to him: ‘If so, they will say My power is limited.’ He (Moshe) said before Him: ‘Here, I will go and appease them.’ He (God) said: ‘Now you will see if My word occurs — they will not listen to you.’ Moshe went to appease them. He said to them: ‘Is God’s power limited? Behold, He struck the rock and water flowed, etc., then He can also provide bread.’ They said: °‘This is a compromise — He does not have the power to fulfill our request.”’ This is what is meant when it says, “Moshe went out and spoke to the people.” When they didn’t listen to him — “He gathered seventy men, etc.”
And did not cease. They did not prophesy, except for that day alone — this is clearly stated by Sifri. But Onkelos renders “and did not cease” — prophesy did not cease from them.
Two people remained. Of those chosen. They said, ‘We are not worthy of such greatness.’

They were among those inscribed. Among those chosen for the Sanhedrin. They were all inscribed specifically by names, and by drawing lots.
