Since the appropriate amount for twelve tribes was six for each tribe, except for two tribes, each of whom received only five, Moshe said: No tribe will listen to me to subtract one elder from its tribe. What did he do? He took seventy two notes, wrote “elder” on seventy °and left two blank. He then chose six from each tribe, totaling seventy two. He told them, ‘Take your notes from the container.’ Whoever chose “elder” was sanctified; to those who chose the empty ones, he said, “The Omnipresent does not want you.”
The youth ran. °Some say this was Gershom, the son of Moshe.

Destroy them. Burden them with communal responsibility, °and they will destroy themselves. Another interpretation: Detain them °in prison, because they prophesied that Moshe would die and Yehoshua would bring the Israelites into the land.
Are you vengeful for me? Are you my avenger? Do you take my vengeance for me?

לִי meaning the same as בִּשְׁבִילִי, “for my sake.” קִנְאָה always denotes a person who takes something to heart, whether to avenge or to assist. “enprenment” in Old French, °one who grasps the bulk of the burden.
Moshe entered °From the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
Into the camp. °Everyone entered his [own] tent.

Entered. The connotation is to enter a house, as in, “Bring it into your house.” The source for this general connotation is, “He gathers, but does not know who will bring it in.” This teaches that he did not visit punishment upon them until each of the righteous had entered his tent.
And He caused to fly. Caused to fly. Similarly, “for it flies by quickly,” Also, “they flew by and passed through.”
And spread them. It spread, as in, “Behold, they are spread over the face of all the land,” “I will spread you into the wilderness.”
About two amos. They flew to a height which °corresponded with a person’s heart, so that it would not be tedious to gather them, °neither to rise nor to bend.
He who gathered the least. The one who gathered least of all — the lazy and the lame — gathered ten heaps.
They spread them. They spread them into numerous piles.
Before it was finished. As Targum [Onkelos] renders, עַד לָא פְסַק, °(before it was finished). Another interpretation: There was no opportunity to cut it with his teeth, when he expired.

[Miriam] spoke. דִּבּוּר always connotes harshness, as it says, “The man who rules the land spoke harshly with us.” But אֲמִירָה always connotes pleading, as it says, “He said, please, my brothers, do not be wicked,” “He said, please hear my words.” נָא always connotes a request.

Miriam and Aharon spoke. She opened the discussion first, so Scripture gives her precedence. °How did Miriam know that Moshe separated from his wife? R’ Noson says: Miriam was at Tziporah’s side when Moshe was told that Eldad and Meidad were prophesying in the camp. When Tziporah heard, she said, ‘Woe to their wives if they become attached to prophecy, because they will separate from their wives the way my husband separated from me.’ Miriam knew from there, and she told Aharon. Now if Miriam, who did not intend to slander him, was punished this way, certainly someone who relates slander about his fellow.
The Cushite woman. This teaches that everyone agreed to her beauty, °just as everyone agrees to the blackness of the Cushite.
Cushite. [כּוּשִׁית is] numerically equivalent to יְפַת מַרְאֶה, (“beautiful in appearance.”)
Concerning the woman. °Concerning her divorce.

For, he married a Cushite woman. What does the Torah teach? You find a woman beautiful in appearance but not beautiful in deed; in deed, but not in appearance. But this one was beautiful in everything.
The Cushite woman. Because of her beauty, she was called “Cushite,” like a man who calls his attractive son “Cushite” to ward off the power of the evil eye over him.
For, he married a Cushite woman. And now divorced her.
Is it only. °With him alone that God spoke.
Did He not also [speak] with us. Yet we did not abstain from marital relations.
Humble. Bent low and forbearing.

Suddenly. He revealed Himself to them °suddenly, when they were ritually unclean because of marital relations, and they cried, °”Water! Water!” To inform them that Moshe acted properly in separating from his wife, since the Divine Presence revealed Itself to him constantly, with no designated time for the Word.
Come out, all three of you. This teaches that all three were summoned with a single word, which is impossible for the mouth to say and the ear to hear.

In a pillar of cloud. °He went alone, unlike the custom of mortals. When a mortal king goes to war, he goes out with a large retinue, when he goes in peace, he goes with only a few. But the custom of the Holy One, Blessed is He, is to go to war alone, as it is said, “[God is] a warrior,” and goes in peace with a large retinue, as is said, “God rides with twenty two thousand angels.”
He called [to] Aharon and Miriam. °So that they would be drawn away and leave the courtyard towards the Word.

Both of them went out. Why did He draw them away and separate them from Moshe? Because we recite some of a person’s qualities in his presence, and all of them when he is not present. We find this about Noach. When he was not present it is said, “A righteous man, flawless,” but in his presence it is said, “For I have seen that you are righteous before Me.” Another interpretation: So that he should not hear Aharon’s rebuke.
Please listen to my words. ° נָא is interpreted strictly as a request.
If there will be your prophet. If °you will have prophets.
[I,] Adonoy will make Myself known to him in a vision. °The Divine Presence of My Name will not be revealed to him in the illuminated reflection, but in a dream and vision.
Mouth to mouth. °I told him to separate from his wife. Where did I tell him? At Sinai, “Go tell them ‘Return to your tents,’ but you remain with Me here.”

In a vision, and not in riddles. “In a vision” — this is the vision of the word, for I explain My word to him in the clearest form, I do not conceal it in riddles the way it was said to Yechezkel, “Present a riddle, etc.” Perhaps [this refers to] the vision of the Divine Presence? The Torah teaches, “you cannot see My Presence.”
He gazes at the likeness of Adonoy. This is the vision of the back, according to what is said, “But you may see what is behind Me.”

About My servant, about Moshe. It does not say, ‘about My servant Moshe,’ but ‘about My servant, about Moshe’ — about My servant, even if he were not Moshe, about Moshe, even if he were not My servant, It would have been appropriate for you to have been in awe of him. Certainly since he is My servant, and the king’s servant is [as] the king. You should have said, ‘The king does not love him gratuitously.’ And if you say that °I am not aware of his actions, then this (statement) is worse than the first!

Adonoy’s anger flared against them and He left. After He informed them of their reprehensible behavior, He decreed excommunication against them. Certainly a mortal, then, should not be angry with his fellow until he informs him of his reprehensible behavior.
The cloud departed. Afterward, “Behold, Miriam was leprous, like snow.” This is compared to a king who said to a pedagogue, ‘Punish my son, but do not punish him until I leave, as I pity him.’
We have foolishly done. As Targum [Onkelos] translates, from the word אֱוִיל, “fool.”
Please, let her not be, this our sister.
Like the dead. Since the leper is considered dead. °Just as the dead cause ritual defilement when entering [a room], so does the leper cause ritual defilement when entering.

That, since he came from his mother’s womb. “Our mother” should have been said, but Scripture euphemises. Similarly, “half his flesh” — “half our flesh” should have been said, but Scripture euphemises. That, since she came from our mother’s womb, [what] she [suffers] is ours, as if half our flesh were eaten away. This is similar to what is said, “for he is our brother, our flesh.” The simple interpretation also appears the same. °It is unconscionable for a brother to allow his sister to remain as if dead.

That, since he came. Since he [also] came from the mother’s womb of this one who has the power to help but does not, then half his own flesh is eaten away, as his brother, is his flesh. Another interpretation [of] “Please, let her not be like the dead.” If you do not heal her through prayer, °who will confine her, and who will purify her? I can not possibly examine her, as I am related, and a relative cannot examine the symptoms of leprosy. And there is no other kohein in the world. This is [what is meant by] “that, since he came from his mother’s womb.”

Please, God, please heal her. Scripture comes to teach proper behavior — that one who requests something from his fellow must say two or three words of supplication, then, afterward, make his requests.

Saying. What does the Torah teach? He (Moshe) said to Him, °‘Answer me, [as to] whether or not You will cure her’ — until He did answer, “If her father were to spit, etc.” R’ Elazar son of Azariah said, in four places, Moshe asked the Holy One, Blessed is He, that He answer him [as to] whether or not He would grant his requests. Similarly, “Moshe spoke before God, saying, etc.” What does the Torah teach by writing “saying”? ‘Answer me [as to] whether or not You will redeem them’ — until He did answer him, “Now you will see, etc.” Similarly, “Moshe spoke to God, saying, ‘let God, the God of the spirit of all flesh, appoint’.” He answered: “Take for you.” Similarly, “I pleaded with God at that time, saying.” He answered him, “Enough, for you.”

Please heal her. Why did not Moshe pray at length? So that the Israelites should not say, “His sister is suffering, and he stands and prolongs his prayer.” (Another interpretation: So that the Israelites should not say, For his sister he prays at length, but for us he does not pray at length).

If (lit. “and”) her father were to spit in her face. °If her father were to display, to her, an angry face, would she not be humiliated for seven days? °Certainly, then, in the case of the Divine Presence, [she should be humiliated] for fourteen days. However, it is sufficient that the derivative equal the source of its derivation. Therefore, even with My rebuke, let her be confined for seven days.

And after that, she may join again. I say that all אֲסִיפוֹת mentioned regarding lepers are related to his expulsion from the camp. When he is cured, he is brought into the camp. Thus, אֲסִיפָה is written concerning him, meaning bringing in.
The people did not depart. This honor was accorded her by the Omnipresent for °the one hour she remained with Moshe when he was cast into the river, as it is said, “his sister stood from afar, etc.

Send, for yourself. °Why is the chapter of the spies adjacent to the chapter of Miriam? Because she was punished over the matter of her slanderous conversation about her brother, and those wicked men saw, but did not accept reproof.

Send, for yourself. °According to your opinion I do not command you. If you wish, send. Because the Israelites came and said, ‘let us send men before us,’ as it is said, “all of you approached me, etc.” °Moshe conferred with the Shechinah. He (Hashem) said, ‘I told them that it is good, as it is said, “I will bring you up from the suffering of Egypt, etc.” By their lives! I’ll give them °an opportunity for error with the report of the spies, so that they will not inherit it.
By the word of Adonoy. °With His permission — He did not stop him.
All of them [were] men of distinction. אֲנָשִׁים in Scripture always °refers to distinction. °At that time they were righteous.
Moshe called Hosheiah, etc. He prayed for him, °‘may Hashem save you from [joining] the counsel of the spies.”
Go up this [way], to the south. °This was the worst of Eretz Yisroel. This is the method of merchants, first they display the worst, and then they display the best.
What the land is. °Some countries nurture strong men, some countries nurture °weaklings, some °grow large populations, some diminish the populace.
Are they strong or weak. °He gave them a sign. If they live in open cities, they are strong, since they are confident of their strength. But if they live in fortified cities, they are weak.
Are they open. Targum [Onkelos] translates, הַבְּפַצְחִין (“whether in open cities”), cities that are exposed and open, for lack of a wall.
Is it good. With excellent, prolific wells and deep water shelves.
Does it have trees. Whether there is, among them, °a righteous man to protect them with his merit.
The first ripening of the grapes. Days when the grapes were °first ripening.

From the desert of Tzin until Rechov, at the entrance of Chamas. They went along °the length and width of its borders, like the form of the [Greek] gamma [G] They proceeded along the direction of the southern border from the eastern to the western corner as Moshe had commanded, “go up this way, to the south” by way of the southeastern border until the sea, as the sea is the western border. From there, they turned and proceeded along the entire western border by the seashore, until the entrance of Chamas, which is near Hor Hahar, at the northwestern corner, as the boundaries of the land are explicitly stated in the portion of “These are the journeys.”

And [he] came to Chevron: Caleiv went there alone and prostrated himself [in prayer] °at the grave of the patriarchs, so that he would not be enticed by his companions to join in their design. Accordingly, it says, “I will give him (Caleiv) the land on which he walked,” and it is written, “they gave to Caleiv, Chevron.”

Was built seven years. Is it possible that Cham built Chevron, for his youngest son Canaan, before he built Tzo’an, for his eldest son Mitzrayim? Rather, it was °built up with everything good, seven times more than Tzoan. °This informs you of the praiseworthiness of Eretz Yisroel, for nothing in Eretz Yisroel is more °barren than Chevron that is why it was set aside as a cemetery. Nothing is as excellent, among all the countries, as Mitzrayim, as it is said, “Like Hashem’s garden, like the land of Mitzrayim.” And Tzoan was the most excellent in the land of Mitzrayim, for the seat of royalty was there, as it is said, “for his ministers were in Tzoan.” Yet, Chevron was seven times better.
A branch. A branch of the grapevine °with a cluster of grapes hanging from it.

They carried it between two on a pole. From the plain meaning of the statement “they carried it on a pole,” °do I not know that it was with two [carriers]? What does the Torah teach by saying “between two”? With two poles. How was this? °Eight took the cluster, one took the fig, one the pomegranate. Yehoshuah and Caleiv did not take anything, since the sole purpose of the others was to deliver a slanderous report — ‘Just as its fruit is strange, so are its people strange.’ If you want to know how much one of them weighed, go and learn from the stones they set up in Gilgal. Each man carried one stone from the Yardein on his shoulder, and set it up in Gilgal. The Rabbis determined that each weighed forty se’in, and tradition teaches that the load a man can carry on his shoulder is only a third of the load he can carry when others assist him.

They returned from spying the land, at the end of forty days. But is not [the land] four hundred by four hundred parsa’os, and the average person’s traveling distance is ten parsa’os a day, and then there was a traveling distance of forty days from east to west, and they traversed its length and breadth? But as it was revealed before the Holy One, Blessed is He, that He would sentence them with a day for a year, he shortened the way before them.
They went and came. What is [meant by] “they went”? °To compare their going with their coming. Just as their coming was with an evil design, so was their going, with an evil design.
They brought word back to them. °To Moshe and Aharon.
Flowing with milk and honey. A falsehood in which °some truth is not stated at the beginning, cannot be maintained in the end.
Fortified. The word connotes strength. Targum [Onkelos] renders it כְּרִיכַן, meaning circular fortresses. In Aramaic, כְּרִיךְ means “circular.”
Amalek dwells, etc. °Because they had already been burnt by Amalek, the spies mentioned them, to frighten them.
And next to the Yardein. יַד, like its plain meaning, next to the Yardein, and you will be unable to cross.
Caleiv silenced. He silenced °them all.

To [hear about] Moshe. To hear what he would say about Moshe. He cried out, saying: ‘Is it only this that the son of Amram did to us’? °The listener thought that he intended to slander him. Since they were resentful towards Moshe because of the spies’ report, they were all silent, in order to hear the slander about him. He said: ‘But did he not split the sea for us, and bring down the manna for us, and cause the quail to be blown to us’?
We can surely go up. °Even to heaven, and even if he tells us to build ladders and go up there, we will succeed at whatever he says!
[He] silenced. The meaning is “silence.” Similarly, “silence, all flesh”! “silence, for it is not to be mentioned.” This is a person’s way. Someone who wants to quiet a group of people says, “sh-sh”!
They are more powerful than we. As if it were possible, they said this °about the One above.

Which consumes its inhabitants. Wherever we passed we found them °burying the dead. But the Holy One, Blessed is He, did this for their benefit, so that they would be preoccupied with their grief and pay no attention to them.
Men of dimensions. Big and tall, who need to be measured, like Golias, “Whose height was six amos and a zeres.” Similarly, “ אִישׁ מָדוֹן,” a man of dimensions.
The giants. Giants, children of Shamchazai and Azael, °who fell from heaven in the days of Enosh.
And so we appeared in their eyes. We heard them °say to each other, ‘There are ants in the vineyard like people.’
The giant. °Who make the sun a necklace by their height.
The entire community The Sanhedrin members.
Would we had died. °Would that we had died.
Let us appoint (lit. place) a head. As Targum [Onkelos] renders, “Let us appoint a head,” ‘Let us appoint a king over us.’ The Rabbis, of blessed memory, interpret this as referring to idolatry.
Do not rebel. °Consequently, “and you do not be afraid, etc.
For they are [as] our bread. We will consume them °like bread.

Their protection (lit. shade) is removed from them. °Their shield and strength. The righteous among them have died — Iyov, who shielded them with his merit. (Another interpretation: The Omnipresent’s shield has been removed from them.)
They should be stoned. °Yehoshua and Caleiv.
When the glory of Adonoy. °The Cloud descended there.
Until where. °To what degree.
Will . . . provoke me. [יְנַאֲצוּנִי means] will they anger me.
Despite all the signs. Because of all the miracles I performed for them, they should have believed that I am capable of fulfilling my promise.
And [I will] annihilate them. °As Targum [Onkelos] renders it, meaning annihilation. °Perhaps you will ask, ‘what will I do about the oath to the patriarchs’?
I shall make you into a greater nation. As you are descended from them.
But Egypt will hear. They will hear °that You killed them.

That You . . . brought up. כִּי is used to denote “that.” And they saw that You brought them up, with Your great power, from among them. When they hear that You killed them, they will not say that they sinned against You. Rather, they will say that, against them, You were able to wage war, but against the inhabitants of the land, You were not able to wage war. This is [the meaning of the following]:

They will say, concerning (lit. to) the inhabitants of this land. Like עַל, “concerning” the inhabitants of this land. What will they say about them? What is said at the end of the subject, because of Hashem’s inability. Since they have heard that You, God, dwell in their midst, and You, Hashem, are revealed to them before their eyes, all in a loving way, and they are not aware that Your love for them was removed from them, until now.
If You kill this nation like a single man. °Suddenly. As a result, the nations who have heard etc.

Because of [Adonoy’s] inability. Because the inhabitants of the land are strong and valorous, and Pharaoh is not the same as thirty-one kings. This is what they will say about the inhabitants of this land. Because of inability. Since He was not able to bring them, He slaughtered them.
[In]ability. °This is an abstract noun.
Let my Master’s power be enhanced. °By fulfilling Your word.
As You spoke, saying: What is the statement?

Adonoy, slow to anger. At the righteous and at the wicked. When Moshe ascended on high, he found the Holy One, Blessed is He, sitting and writing, “Hashem is slow to anger.” He (Moshe) said to Him, ‘to the righteous’? The Holy One, Blessed is He, said to him, ‘even to the wicked’! He (Moshe) said to Him, ‘let the wicked perish’! He said to him ‘by your life, you will need this thing.’ When the Israelites sinned with the [golden] calf and the spies, Moshe prayed before Him with “slow to anger.” The Holy One, Blessed is He, said: “But you said to Me ‘to the righteous”’? He (Moshe) said to Him: “But You said to me, ‘Even to the wicked’.”
Acquit. °Those who repent.
[He] does not acquit. Those who do not repent.
As you spoke. Because of your statement, °”lest they say, ‘because of Hashem’s inability’.”
However. Like, ‘However, I will do the following to them.
As I Live. This denotes an oath. °Just as I live and My glory will fill all the earth, so shall I fulfill to them, “for, all the people who see, etc. . . . If they will see the land.”
Have tested Me. Like its plain meaning.
These ten times. °Twice at the [splitting of the] sea, twice with the manna, twice with the quail, etc., as stated in Maseches Arachin.

If they will see. °They will not see. (If they will see the land. This passage should be rearranged [as follows]: As I live, for all the men, if they will see the land and yet My glory will fill all the earth, so that My Name will not be desecrated through this plague [by those] saying ‘Because of Hashem’s inability to bring them.’ for, I will not kill them suddenly, like a single man, but over forty years, little by little.)
[They] will not see it. They will not see the land.

A different spirit. °Two spirits, one verbal, and one in his heart. To the spies he said, ‘I am with you in your plan,’ but in his heart he intended to tell the truth. Because of this, he was able to silence them, as it is said, “Caleiv silenced [the people],” since they thought he would speak as they did. Thus it is said in the book of Yehoshua, “I (Caleiv) brought back word to him (Moshe) °according to what was in my heart — but not according to what was in my mouth.
And followed Me fully. °He followed Me full-heartedly. This is a shortened passage.
To which he came. °Chevron will be given to m.

Will cast out [the inhabitants] from it. As Targum [Onkelos] renders it, “they will cast out from it.” They will cast out the giants and the people who are in it. But it should not be translated “will inherit it,” unless the text reads יִירָשֶׁנָּה .
The Amaleki, etc. If you go there °they will kill you, since I am not with you.
Tomorrow, turn. Back and travel, etc.
Wicked congregation, etc. °These are the spies. From here [we derive] °that a congregation is ten.
Those who provoke. °The Israelites against me.
The complaints of Bnei Yisroel which they, the spies provoked them into complaining against me, I have heard.
As I live. This denotes an oath. ‘If [I do] not, etc., so I shall do, °if it were possible to say, I do not live.
As you have spoken. You requested from Me, “Or would that we had died in this desert.”

All of you who were counted according to your numbers. All those counted in every census in which you were counted. For example, going and coming with the army, and contributing the shekolim. Everyone counted in all those tallies will die. They are the following: From the age of twenty, etc. This excludes the tribe of Levi, who were not counted from the age of twenty.

Your corpses — yours. As Targum [Onkelos] renders [(דִי לְכוֹן) “yours”]. Since He discussed °bringing the children into the land, and He now wants to say ‘but you will die,’ it is appropriate, here, to say “yours.”

Forty years. Not one of them died °before the age of sixty. This is why the decree was for forty [years], so that those who were twenty years old would reach the age of sixty. °The first year was included, although it preceded the sending of the spies, because, from the time that they made the golden calf, the plan for this decree was formulated, But He waited until their measure was filled. This is [the meaning of] what is said, “on my day of reckoning — with the spies — I will take their sin into account.” Here, too, it is said, “you must bear your sins,” [plural] two sins, that of the calf, and that of the complaint. In calculating their ages, He considered °part of the year as the whole, so that when they entered their sixtieth year, those who had been twenty years old died.
They will bear [the burden of] your dissoluteness. As Targum [Onkelos] renders, “they will receive [punishment for] your sins.”
My displeasure. °You diverted your hearts from following Me. תְּנוּאָה denotes turning away, like, “for her father restrained her [from her vow].”

Who returned and provoked [the] complaints against him. When they returned from spying on the land, they incited the entire congregation against him by issuing a derogatory report — those men died. הוֹצָאַת דִּבָּה always denotes directed speech, where the tongue is plied to report about someone, like, “causing the lips of sleepers to murmur.” It may be either good or bad. This is why it says here “who spread evil slander against the land,” since דִּבָּה may be good.
Slander. Parlerie in Old French.

In a plague, before Adonoy. By the particular death suited to them, measure for measure. They sinned with the tongue, so their tongues were distended until their navel, and maggots came from their tongues and entered their navel. This is why it says, בַּמַּגֵּפָה, and not בְּמַּגֵּפָה . And this is [the meaning of] “before Hashem” — as particularly suited to them, according to the attributes of the Holy One, Blessed is He, Who metes out measure for measure.
Yehoshua . . . and Caleiv . . . lived, etc. °What does the Torah teach by saying, “lived, from among those men”? It teaches that they took the spies’ portion in the land, replacing them in life.
To the peak of the mountain. This was the route going up to Eretz Yisroel.
We are ready to go up to the place. To Eretz Yisroel.
Of which Adonoy spoke. To give to us — let us go up there.
For we have sinned. Since we said, “Is it not better for us to return to Egypt.”
It will not succeed. °Your actions will not succeed.
For, you turned. As if to say, ‘for this will befall you °because you turned, etc.’

They defiantly. The word [וַיַעְפִּלוּ] denotes strength. Similarly, “behold, [the wicked] are towering.” Engres, in Old French, denoting willfulness. Similarly, “the fortress of the daughter of Zion,” “fortress and stronghold.” But Midrash Tanchuma explains it as denoting darkness — they went in darkness, without permission.
And crushed them. Like, “I crushed it, grinding it [well].” Blow after blow.
Until Chormah. The place was named °to commemorate this incident.
(When you arrive. He informed them that they would enter the land.)
When you make a fire-offering. °This does not denote a command. Rather, when you come there, and it occurs to you to make a fire-offering.
A pleasing fragrance. °Satisfying to Me.
By verbalizing as a pledge or as a donation. Or, that you make the fire-offering °in order to fulfill the holiday obligation which I have required you to perform during the holiday.

The one bringing [his offering] should present. °You should present libations and a meal-offering for each animal. The meal- offering is to be completely consumed, °with the oil absorbed in it, °and the wine [is poured] into the bowls, as we learned in Maseches Sukkah.
For the one sheep. This relates to everything stated above — the meal- offering, the oil, and the wine.
If (lit. or) for a ram. °If it is a ram. The Rabbis extrapolate, ‘ אוֹ ’ includes °the “palgas” in the libations of the ram.
A fire-offering [of pleasing] fragrance. This refers only to the meal-offering and the oil, but the wine is not a fire-offering, as it is not placed on the fire.
Or for the sheep, etc. Whether of sheep or of goats. כֶּבֶשׂ and שֶׂה are so entitled during their first year; אַיִל from the age of thirteen months and one day.

According to the number which you offer. °According to the number of animals which you offer as sacrifices, so shall you make the libations for each of them. According to the number of animals, the number of libations.

Just as it is for yourselves, so shall it be for the proselyte. Like you, so is the proselyte. This is the Hebrew style, “Like Hashem”’s garden, like the land of Egypt” — so is the land of Egypt. °”Like me, like you, like my people, like your people.”

At your coming to the land. This “coming” is different from all the “comings” in the Torah. With all of them it says, “when you come,” “when all of you come.” Therefore, all are learned from each other. Since Scripture specified with one of them that it is only after inheriting and settling, all of them are the same. But with this, it is said, “at your coming.” As soon as they entered it (the land) and ate its bread, they were obligated with the mitzvah of challah.

[From] the first portion of your doughs. When you knead the amount of dough that you generally knead in the desert — how much is that? “They measured it with an omer,” “An omer per person” (the amount is forty-three and one-fifth eggs) — you shall separate [the terumah-gift] from its first portion. As if to say, ‘before you eat the first portion from it, separate one loaf as a terumah-gift for the sake of Hashem”.’
A loaf. Tortel in Old French.

Like the terumah-gift of the granary. °For which no specific amount is required, but not like like the terumah-offering from the tithe, °for which a specific amount is required. However, the sages required a specific amount: For the home maker, one twenty-fourth, for the commercial baker, one forty-eighth.

Of the first portion of your doughs. Why is this said? Because it says, “The first portion of your dough,” I would understand this as °the first of the loaves. The Torah therefore teaches, “of the first portion” — part of it, but not all of it.

You shall give to Adonoy, as a terumah- offering. As we have not heard of a specific amount for the challah-offering, it says, “you shall give” — it should consist of °an amount sufficient for “giving.”

If you should err and not fulfill. this refers to idol worship. which was categorized within all the commandments for which the community brings an ox, but Scripture here removes it from the category, °to indicate that it requires an ox as a burnt-offering, and a goat as a sin-offering.

If you err, etc. Scripture speaks here of idol worship. But perhaps it refers to one of all the [other] commandments? The Torah therefore teaches, “all of these commandments” — °a single commandment which is equivalent to all the commandments. Just as someone who transgresses all the commandments casts off the yoke, breaks the covenant, and brazenly defies [the Torah], so with [someone who transgresses] this commandment, he casts off the yoke, breaks the covenant, °and brazenly defies [the Torah]. Which is this? Idol worship.
Which Adonoy said to Moshe. “I am . . .,” and “you must not have . . .” °we heard from the mouth of the Omnipotent, as it is written, “Hashem” spoke once, but I heard two.”

All that [Adonoy] commanded. This teaches that if one admits to idolatry, it is as if he had denied the entire Torah, and all that the prophets prophesied, as it is said, “from the day that Hashem” commanded and onward.”

If, it was obscured from the eyes of the congregation, having been done in error. If, because of the seers of the community, this transgression was committed through error. [For example,] they erred, °and ruled that one of the forms of service is permitted for idol worship.

לְחַטָּת, as a sin-offering. The ‘ א ’ is missing, because this is not like the other sin-offerings. All of the sin-offerings in the Torah which are brought with an olah-offering, the sin-offering precedes the olah, as it is said, “he shall make the second one an olah.” But with this, the olah precedes the sin-offering.
They have brought their offering as a fire-offering to Adonoy. This refers to that which is stated in our parshah, namely °the ox as the olah-offering, as it is said, “a fire-offering to Adonoy.”
And their sin-offering. This refers to the goat.
Will sin erroneously. °Through idolatry.
A yearling she-goat. For other transgressions, the individual brings a sheep or goat, °but for this, a goat is designated.
High handedly. Intentionally.
Blasphemes. Reviles, like, “despised and reviled,” “which the servants of the king of Ashur reviled.” °In addition, the Rabbis derive from here that someone who curses Hashem” is subject to “koreis.”
The word of Adonoy. The prohibition against idol worship was °by the word of the Omnipotent, the rest by the word of Moshe.
Its iniquity is upon it. °During the time his sin is within him — if he has not repented.
[Bnei Yisroel] were in the desert and they found. Scripture speaks disparagingly of the Israelites. °They kept only the first Shabbos, then this person came and desecrated the second.
Those who found him gathering. °They warned him, but he did not desist from gathering, even after they found and warned him.
Since it was not specified, what was to be done with him. [They did not know] °how to execute him, but they knew that someone who desecrates the Shabbos must be put to death.
Shall stone. Constantly do. Fisant in Old French. Similarly, הָלוֹךְ, alant. °Similarly, “constantly remember,” and “constantly keep.”
Brought him outside. From here [we derive] that the stoning platform was outside, far from the courthouse.

To make for themselves, tzitzis-fringes. °So named because of the fringes hanging from it, like, “He took me by the fringes of my head.” Another interpretation: “tzizis” because of “when you see it,” like “watching from the openings.”
Blue [wool]. The blue dye °of the chilazon-fish.
You will remember all of Adonoy’s commandments. As °the numerical value of צִיצִית is 600, °and the eight threads and five knots equal 613.

And you will not search after [the desire of] your hearts. This is similar to “from spying the land.” The heart and eye are the body’s spies, bringing it sins. The eye sees, the heart lusts, and the body sins.
I am Adonoy. Faithful in rewarding.
Your God. °Faithful in exacting punishment.
Who brought you out. I redeemed you °on condition that you accept my decrees.

I am Adonoy your God. Why is this said again? So that the Israelites should not say: “Why did the Omnipresent command? Was it not so that we should perform [the commandments] and be rewarded? Let us not perform, and not be rewarded”! Even against your will, I am your king. Similarly, it says, “[As I live . . .] if I shall not, with a mighty hand . . . rule over you.” °Another interpretation. Why is the exodus from Egypt mentioned? It was I who distinguished, in Egypt, between the [reproductive] drop which was the firstborn, and that which was not the firstborn. It is I who will distinguish, and punish those who attach [fringes dyed with] °indigo dye on their garments, and claim that it is the “techeiles” dye. From R’ Moshe Hadarshan’s commentary I transcribed: Why is the chapter of the “gatherer” adjacent to the chapter of idolatry? To teach that the Shabbos desecrator is like an idolator, since it (Shabbos), too, is equated with the entire Torah. This is stated in Ezra: “You descended on mount Sinai and gave Your nation the Torah and the commandments, etc., and You made Your sacred Shabbos known to them.” The portion of tzitzis, also for this reason, is adjacent to these [portions] — since it, too, is equivalent to all the commandments, as it is said, “you will perform all the commandments.”

On the corners of their garments. This corresponds with, “I carried you on the wings of eagles.” On the four corners — °but not on a garment with three, or with five [corners]. This corresponds with the four expressions of redemption which were stated in Egypt — “I will bring [you] out,” “I will save [you],” “I will redeem [you],” “I will take [you].”

A thread of blue. [תְּכֵלֶת] so named because of the [Egyptians’] loss of their firstborn. The targum — translation of שִׁכּוּל, “loss of a child,” is תִּכְלָא . And they were struck down at night. The color of “ techeiles” is similar to the sky which darkens during evening. Its eight threads °correspond with the eight days the Israelites waited, from the time they left Egypt, until they sang at the [Reed] Sea.
Korach took. °This passage is beautifully expounded by Midrash R’ Tanchuma.

Korach took. He took himself to a different side, to be °disassociated from the community and to cast aspersion on the kehunah. This is why Onkelos translates וְאִתְפְּלֵג, he separated himself from the rest of the community in order to maintain the dispute. Similarly, “why does your heart take you?”— (i.e.,) it takes you to separate you from other people. °Another interpretation [of] “Korach took”: He won over the heads of the Sanhedrin among them, with flattering words, as it is said, “take Aharon,” “take words with you.”

The son of Yitzhar, the son of Kehos, the son of Levi. But °Scripture does not mention, “the son of Yaakov,” since he [Yaakov] implored [God] for compassion on himself that his name be omitted from their dispute, as it is said, “let my honor not be identified with their assembly.” °Where is his (Yaakov’s) name mentioned with Korach? At the genealogical identification [of the Levites] at the platform, in Divrei Hayamim, as it is said, “the son of Evyasaf, the son of Korach, the son of Yitzhar, the son of Kehos, the son of Levi, the son of Yisroel.”

And Dasan and Aviram. Because the tribe of Reuven made their camp at the south, °neighboring Kehos and his sons, who camped at the south, they joined Korach in his dispute. °”Woe to the wicked, woe to his neighbor”! °Why did Korach see fit to dispute Moshe? He envied °Elitzafan the son of Uziel for his leadership. Moshe appointed him leader over the sons of Kehos, by the word of God. Korach said, ‘Father had four brothers, as it is said: “The sons of Kehos, etc.” Amram was the firstborn. His two sons assumed great distinction — one (Moshe) is the monarch, the other (Aharon) the Kohein Gadol. Who should appropriately assume the second [position], if not I, the son of Yitzhar, second to Amram? Yet he appointed, as leader, the son of the youngest of all of his (Amram’s) brothers. I will oppose him, and nullify everything he said.’ What did he do? He rose up and gathered two hundred fifty heads of Sanhedrin, mostly from the neighboring tribe of Reuven — they were Elitzur the son of Shdeiur, and his companions, and the like, as it is said, “leaders of the congregation, who were called to meetings,” and it says above, °”those called from the congregation (leaders of their ancestral tribes).” He clothed them in °garments made completely of techeiles. They came and stood before Moshe and said to him: “Does a garment made completely of techeiles require tzitzis, or not?’ He said to them: “It is required.” They began scoffing at him. “How is it possible that a garment made of other material is absolved by a single thread of techeiles, yet one made completely of techeiles cannot absolve itself?”
The sons of Reuvein. °Dasan and Aviram, and On the son of Peles.
You have [taken] too much for yourselves. °You have taken much more distinction for yourselves [than is appropriate].
Are all holy. °They all heard the Word, at Sinai, from the mouth of the Almighty.

Why do you raise yourselves. °If you took the monarchy, you should not have chosen the kehunah for your brother. °You were not alone in hearing, at Sinai, “I am God your God”— the entire community heard.

He fell upon his face. °Because of the dispute, as this was, already, °their fourth despicable act. They sinned with the golden calf — “Moshe implored . . . “ With the complainers — “Moshe prayed . . .” With the spies — “Moshe said to God, If Egypt should hear. . .” At Korach’s dispute, his hands were weakened. This is compared to a prince who acted despicably against his father. His intimate friend placated him the first, second, and third times, but at the fourth despicable act, the friend’s hands were weakened. He said: “How long can I impose upon the king? Perhaps he will no longer receive me.”

[In the] morning, [Adonoy] will make known. °This is a time when we are intoxicated, and it would be improper [for us] to appear in His Presence. His intention was to delay, so that they might repent.
[In the] morning, Adonoy will make known who is [qualified to be] His. °For the Levite services.
And who is holy. For the kehunah.

He will bring. °Them close to Him. Targum [Onkelos] demonstrates this: “He will bring into His presence.” “He will bring into His service.” According to the Midrashic interpretation of “morning”: Moshe said to them, ‘God marked His universe with boundaries. Can you possibly transform morning into evening? that is how possible it is for you to nullify this, as it is said, “it became evening and it became morning, and He separated” Similarly, “Aharon was separated to be consecrated etc.”

Do this: Take, for yourselves, fire pans. Why did he see fit to tell them this? He said to them, “the gentile way is to have a variety of rituals, with many priests, [not all] gathered in one Temple. We have only one God, one Ark, one Torah, one Altar, and one Kohein Gadol. Yet you — two hundred and fifty men — seek the kehunah Gedolah! I, too, will acquiesce. Here you have the most precious service, the incense, more precious than all the sacrifices. But a deadly poison is placed in it, which consumed Nadav and Avihu.” He, therefore, warned them, “The man who will be chosen by Adonoy, he is the holy one.” He was already holy. Do we not know that the chosen one is holy? Rather, Moshe said to them, “I tell you this so that you will not be found guilty. The chosen one will survive, but all of you will be lost.”
Fire pans. Utensils for stoking coals, with a handle.

You have taken [too] much upon yourselves, sons of Levi. [I told you many things which are acceptable to the heart (i.e., reasonable). Another interpretation:] What I have said to you is a matter of great significance. Were they not fools, for he warned them, and yet they undertook to bring the offering? They sinned with their souls, as it is said, “the firepans of these sinners with their souls.” °But Korach who was astute, why did he see fit to engage in this foolishness? His vision deceived him. He saw a great dynasty descending from him — Shmuel, who was equal to Moshe and Aharon. He said, “for his sake, I will be spared.” And twenty four watches arising from his descendants, all prophesying by Divine inspiration, as it is said, “all of these were the sons of Heiman.” He said, “is it possible that all this greatness is destined to arise from me, and I shall remain silent”? This is why he participated, for, he had heard from Moshe’s mouth, that they would all be lost, but one would be spared: “The one whom God will choose, he is holy.” He mistakenly attributed this to himself, but his vision was flawed, as his sons repented. But Moshe saw.
Too much upon yourselves °You have undertaken a great task for yourselves to dispute the Holy One, Blessed is He.

Moshe said to Korach, “Please listen, sons of Levi.” He began speaking gently to him, but when he saw that he was stiff necked, he said, “before the other tribes join and are lost with him, I had better speak with all of them, too.” He began exhorting them, “please listen, sons of Levi.”
And to stand before the congregation. To sing on the platform.
He brought you near. °To the service from which he distanced the rest of the community of Yisroel.

Therefore, °Because of this, you, and your entire congregation who are gathered with you, have assembled against God, for I have acted as His representative in awarding the kehunah to Aharon. This quarrel is not with us.
Moshe sent, etc. From here [we derive] that one should not maintain a dispute, for Moshe sought them out in order to come to terms with them through a peaceful dialogue.
We will not go up. Their own words caused them to stumble — they will have nothing but a downfall.

And [not] given us. The statement relates to Gא (“not”), mentioned above, as if to say, “you have not brought us, and you have not given us an inheritance of fields and vineyards. °You told us, ‘I will bring you up out of the suffering of Egypt to a good land . . . [flowing with milk and honey].’ You brought us out of there, but not to a land flowing with milk and honey did you bring us. Rather, you decreed, against us, that we die in the wilderness, as you said to us, ‘Your corpses will fall in this wilderness’.”
If you put those people’s eyes out, etc. °Even if you send agents to put our eyes out unless we go up to you, we will not go up.
Those people. Like a man who attributes his own curse to someone else.
Moshe was extremely distressed. And Moshe was very grieved.

Do not turn to their offering. According to the plain interpretation, [through] °the incense which they will offer before you tomorrow, do not turn to them. According to the Midrash, he said, “I know °that they have a portion in the continual communal sacrifices. Let their portion not be received by you favorably. Let the fire allow it to remain without consuming it.”

Not a donkey did I sequester from any one of them. I did not take a donkey from any °one of them. Even when I went from Midyan to Egypt and set my wife and sons on a donkey, when °I could have justifiably taken that donkey from them, I took only of my own. Onkelos translates שְׁחָרִית, “sequestered.” In Aramaic, the king’s service is called שַׁחְוַור .
And they. °Your congregation.
And you will offer before Adonoy each man his firepan. The two hundred fifty men among you.

Korach congregated against them. °With mockery. All that night he went to the tribes and enticed them. — “Do you think I am indignant for my sake alone? I am indignant only for the sake of all of you! They came and took all the great offices, the monarchy for himself, and the kehunah for his brother. . .,” until they were all convinced.
The glory of Adonoy appeared. °He came in the pillar of cloud.

Almighty, the God of the spirits. °Knower of thoughts. Your attributes are not like mortal attributes. A mortal king, against whom some of his kingdom acted scurrilously, does not know who the sinner is. Therefore, when he is angry, he punishes them all. But You — to You, all thoughts are revealed, and You know who the sinner is.
If one man. °Has sinned, will You be angry with the entire congregation? °The Holy One, Blessed is He, said: “You have spoken well. I know, and will make known, who sinned and who did not sin.”
Depart (lit. go up). As Targum [Onkelos] renders, (אִסְתַּלָּקוּ), °”depart,” from around Korach’s dwelling.
Moshe rose up. He thought they would treat him with regard, but they did not.
Went out and stood. °With a haughty bearing, to revile and blaspheme, °as “he stood disdainfully for forty days” [at the incident] of Golias.

With their wives, children and infants. Come, see °how inexorably destructive disputes are, for earthly tribunals do not mete out punishment until two pubic hairs have appeared, and the heavenly tribunal until twenty years, but here, even nursing infants perished.
To perform all these deeds. Which I have done by the word of God; °conferring the kehunah Gedolah on Aharon, [appointing] his sons as assistants, and Elitzafan as leader of the Kehosites.
Adonoy has not sent me. Rather, I did everything independently, and he (Korach) is justified in opposing me.
But if Adonoy will create a new creation.

To kill them °with a death no one has ever experienced until now. What is this creation? “The earth will open its mouth and swallow them.” Then, you will know that they angered God, and I spoke according to the word of the Almighty. The Rabbis interpret, °‘if the mouth of the earth was created during the six days of creation, fine, but if not, let God it create [now]!’
Fled from their uproar. Because of °the sound of the earth swallowing them up.
And the fire. °In the firepans.
Scatter yonder. To the ground, °from the firepans.
For, they were sanctified. °The firepans, and may not be used for personal benefit, since they designated them as sacred service utensils.
These sinners with their souls. °They became willful sinners with their souls by disputing the Holy One, Blessed is He.
Hammered. Beaten.
Sheets. Hammered sheets. Tendes, “sheets,” in Old French.
To overlay the altar. °The copper altar.
They shall be for a sign. A reminder, so that they will say, “These belonged to the ones who disputed the kehunah, and were burned.”
And hammered them. Atendirent, “hammered” in Old French.
So as not to be like Korach. °In order not to be like Korach.

As Adonoy spoke to him, through Moshe. Like עָלָיו, “about him.” About Aharon, He spoke to Moshe, [saying] that he and his sons shall be kohanim. Therefore, a stranger should not approach who is not a descendant of Aharon, etc. Similarly, every לִי, לוֹ and לָהֶם next to דִּבּוּר, “speech,” is interpreted as עַל, “about.” According to Midrash, °about Korach, what is [the meaning of] בְּיַד משֶׁה, [literally “in the hand of Moshe,”] [why did] Scripture not write “to Moshe”? This alludes that those who dispute the kehunah °are stricken with tzora'as, as Moshe was stricken in his hand, as it is said, “when he withdrew it, his hand was stricken with tzora’as — white as snow.” This is why Uziyah was stricken with tzora’as.
And atone for them. This was the secret, the angel of death conveyed to him when he [Moshe] ascended to heaven, that incense holds back the plague, as stated in Maseches Shabbos.

He stood between the dead etc. °He grasped the angel and held him against his will. The angel said to him, “Permit me to perform my duty.” He said to him, “Moshe ordered me to stop you.” He said to him, “I represent God, while you represent Moshe.” He said to him, “Moshe says nothing of his own volition, only from the mouth of the Almighty. If you don’t believe me — why the Holy One, Blessed is He, and Moshe are at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting. Come with me and ask.” This is [the meaning of] what is said — Aharon returned to Moshe. °Another interpretation: Why with incense? Because the Israelites were grumbling, and vilifying the incense, saying that it was a deadly poison — because of it, Nadav and Avihu died, because of it, two hundred and fifty men were consumed. The Holy One, Blessed is He, said, ‘You will see that it [incense] halts the plague — it is sinfulness, that kills.’
For, [there is] one staff. Although I divided them into two family groups, the kehunah family separately, and the Levite separately, still, they are a single tribe.
And I will abate. Like “the waters abated,” “the king’s rage abated.”
Among their staffs. He placed it °in the middle, so that they would not claim that, because he placed it near the Divine Presence, it flowered.
Blossomed. Like the plain interpretation.
Buds. This refers to the budding of the fruit, °when the blossoms drop.

And bore ripe almonds. When the fruit was discernible, it was recognized as almonds, as in “the child grew and was weaned.” This term is generally used for fruit of the tree, as in “its buds will become ripening fruit.” °Why almonds? This is the fruit which blossoms more quickly than all fruits. One who callenges the kehunah as well, will be punished quickly, as we find with Uzyah, “the tzora’as emanated from his forehead.” Targum [Onkelos] renders, “it clustered almonds” — a sort of almond cluster, bunched together with each other.
To be preserved as symbol. Of °remembrance that I chose Aharon to serve as kohein, so that they will never again dispute the kehunah.

So that their complaint will end. Like וּתְכַלֶּה תְלוּנּוֹתָם, ‘their’ complaint will end. This term is a singular, °feminine verbal noun, like תְּלוּנָּתָם . murmur-diz, “complaint” in Old French. There is a distinction between תְּלוּנּוֹתָם and תְּלוּנָּתָם . תְּלוּנָּתָם, a single complaint. תְּלוּנּוֹתָם, a singular noun, even when there are many complaints.

Anyone approaching who comes close, etc. We cannot take precautions against this. We are all permitted to enter °the courtyard of the Tent of Meeting. And anyone who advances further than his fellows, and enters into the Tent of Meeting, will die.
Have we been consigned to death? Perhaps °we have been abandoned to die?
Adonoy said to Aharon. He told Moshe °to say to Aharon, To exhort him concerning [precautions] for the benefit of the Israelites, so that they do not enter the Sanctuary.
You, your sons, and your father’s house. °The children of Kehos, Amram’s father.

Will bear the sin of the Sanctuary. I am casting, upon you, the punishment of the unauthorized persons who sin by their involvement with the sacred objects placed in your charge — the Tent, Ark, Table, and sacred vessels. You must station yourselves and warn every unauthorized person who attempts contact.
And you and your sons. The kohanim.
Will bear the sin of your kehunah. Since it is not a charge given to the Levites, you must warn the erring Levites not to come in contact with you during your service.
Also, your brothers. The sons of Gershon and the sons of Merori.
They shall join you. They shall unite with you °in also warning the unauthorized persons not to approach them.
And serve you. By guarding the gateways, and through the appointment, from them, of custodians and °administrators.
A commonor should not approach you. °I admonish you about this.
So that there will be no more wrath. °As there already was, as it is said, “for the wrath has surfaced.”
Given to you as a gift. °Perhaps for your personal, secular service? The Torah, therefore, teaches, “for God,” as specified above, to attend to the mandate — custodians and administrators.
The service as a gift. I have given it to you °as a gift.

Behold, I have given you. With joy. °This term denotes joy, as in, “behold, he is going out to meet you, and when he sees you, he will rejoice in his heart.” This is compared to a king who gave a property to his intimate friend, but did not write and sign a deed, or register it with the authorities. Someone came and claimed the property. The king said to him: “Whoever wishes will come and claim against you. Behold, I will write and sign a deed to you, and register it with the authorites.” Here, too, because Korach came and claimed the kehunah from Aharon, Scripture °presents him with twenty-four kehunah gifts, with the eternal covenant of salt. This is why this chapter was placed here.
The guarding of my terumah-gifts. Which you must °guard in ritual purity.
For consecration. °For greatness.
From the fire. °After the burning of the fire.
[Of] all their sacrifices. °For example, the communal shelamim-offerings.
Their minchah-offerings, their sin-offerings, and their guilt-offerings. As the plain meaning indicates.
Which they return to Me. °This refers to the proselyte’s stolen property.
You shall eat it in the supremely holy. This teaches that the supremely holy offerings °may be eaten only in the Sanctuary courtyard, and by the male kohanim.
Their terumah-gift. °Which was set aside from the thanksgiving-offering, the peace- offering, and the ram of the nazarite.
Of all of the wave-offerings. Since these require waving.
All those ritually pure. °But not those ritually defiled. °Another interpretation of “all those ritually pure” — to include his wife.
Their terumah-gift. This refers to the major terumah-gift.

Like the breast which is waved and like the right thigh. Of the peace-offering, which are eaten by the kohanim, and their wives, children, and servants, for two days and one night. °The firstborn [animal], also, is eaten for two days and one night.

It shall be yours. °R’ Akiva came, and expounded: Scripture adds an additional “being,” so that you should not say, “like the breast and thigh of the thanksgiving-offering, which is only eaten for a day and a night.”
All of the sacred terumah-gifts. Because this parashah is precious, it is generalized at the beginning, generalized at the end, and detailed in between.
An eternal covenant of salt. He made a covenant with Aharon with a robust, enduring object which invigorates others.
A covenant of salt. Like the covenant made with salt, which never spoils.
And you will not have a share among them. °Even in the spoils.
They. °The Levites will bear the sins of the Israelites, since it is incumbent upon them to warn unauthorized persons against approaching them.
Which they must set aside to Adonoy as a terumah-gift. °Scripture calls it “a terumah-gift” until he separates the terumah of the tithe from it.

Your terumah-gift will be considered the same as grain from the granary. The terumah of your tithe is prohibited to unauthorized persons and to the ritually unclean, and they are liable to the death penalty, and to the additional fifth, °like the major terumah- gift, which is called the first portion of grain from the granary.
And [wine and oil of] fully ripened fruit from the cistern. The terumah-gift of wine and oil taken from the cisterns.
Fully ripened fruit (lit. full). The term denotes ripeness. Full produce.

Cistern. This refers to the pit before the press, wherein the wine flows. The word יֶקֶב always denotes an excavation of earth. Similarly, “the king’s cisterns,” referring to the sea of Okiyanus, an excavation dug by the King of the universe.
So must you, too, set aside. Just as the Israelites set aside from their granaries and cisterns, so must you, too, from your tithe, since that is your inheritance.

From all of your gifts you must set aside all of the terumah-gifts of Adonoy. Scripture speaks of °major terumah, [teaching] that if the Levite pre-empted the kohein at the storage bin, and received his tithes before the kohein took the major terumah from the storage bin, the Levite must first set aside one fiftieth of the tithe as major terumah, and then return and set aside the terumah of the tithe.
When you set aside the finest part of it. °After you set aside the terumah of the tithe from it.
It will be considered. °What remains for the Levites [will be considered] completely secular.

Like the produce of the granary. To the Israelite. °So that you should not say, since the Torah calls it “terumah,” as it is said, “for the Israelites’ tithe which they set aside for God as a terumah-gift,” perhaps it is completely forbidden. The Torah therefore teaches, “It will be considered, for the Levites, like the produce of the granary.” Just as that of the Israelite is secular, so is that of the Levite secular.
Anywhere. Even in the cemetery.
You will not bear a sin because of it, etc. °Hence, if you do not set aside, you will bear a sin.
And you will not die. Hence, if you profane, you will die.

This is the statute of the Torah. °Because Satan and the nations of the world taunt Israel, saying, “What is this commandment? °What is the reason for it”? Therefore, the Torah referred to it as חֻקָּה, a statute. I have decreed it, and you are not permitted to question it.
They shall take to you. °It will always be called by your name: °”The cow which Moshe prepared in the wilderness.”
Red, perfect. °It must be perfectly red. If it had °two black hairs, it was disqualified.
Elozor. °The mitzvah was [performed] by the assistant [kohein gadol].
Outside the camp. °Outside the three camps.
[He] shall slaughter it in his presence. °The commoner slaughters while Elozor observes.
Directly facing the Tent of Meeting. °He stands east of Jerusalem, and focuses his gaze on the entrance to the Sanctuary when sprinkling the blood.
[To] the camp. To the camp of the Shechinah, as no one ritually unclean was sent out of two camps °except for the zav, the ba’al keri, and the metzorah.
The kohein shall be impure until the evening. °Rearrange this and extrapolate: “He shall be impure until the evening, and afterwards, he may enter the camp.”

And place [it] outside the camp. °He divided it into three parts. One was placed on the Mount of Olives, and one was placed in the “cheil” partition. That of the watches was outside the Temple courtyard, to supply the outlying city dwellers and all those who needed to be purified. That of the Mount of Olives, for the high priests to consecrate other cows. That of the “cheil” partition, placed as a keepsake by Scriptural decree, as it is said, ”It shall remain with the community of Israel as a keepsake.”
For sprinkling water. For water of sprinkling, similar to, “they cast a stone at me,” “to cast away the horns of the nations,” meaning to throw.

For purification. °The word denotes cleansing, like its plain meaning. °In its halachic sense, however, Scripture entitles it חַטָּאת, “sin-offering,” to teach that it is like a sacred object, and thus prohibited from personal benefit.
He shall cleanse himself with it. °With [these] ashes [of the cow].

A corpse of a [human] soul. Which corpse? That of a human soul. °This excludes that of an animal, whose ritual uncleanliness does not require sprinkling Another interpretation: “Of a [human] soul” °refers to a quarter of blood.

Defiles the Mishkan of Adonoy. °If he enters the Mishkan courtyard, even after ritual immersion, without having been sprinkled on the third and seventh [days]. His impurity remains. Even if he immersed ritually.
Anyone who enters the tent. °While the corpse is inside.

Any open utensil. Scripture refers to °an earthen utensil, which does not admit ritual contamination from its outside, but from its inside. Thus, if its seal is not properly and securely fastened, it is defiled, but if there is a seal fastened to it, it is pure.
Fastened. °The word denotes attachment in Arabic. Similarly, “I have been joined by Godly bonds”— I have been joined to my sister.
In an open field. The Rabbis extrapolate, this includes °the “gollel” and “dofek.” Its plain meaning is that in the open field, where there is no tent, the corpse conveys defilement through touching.
He shall purify him on the seventh day. °This completes the purification.
A person who became ritually unclean, etc. If “Mikdash” was said, °why was “Mishkon” said?. . .etc., as stated in tractate Shevuos.

One who sprinkles the sprinkling waters. The Rabbis say °that the sprinkler is actually pure, and that this teaches °that one who carries the purifying water becomes extremely defiled, so as to contaminate the garments he wears, unlike one who touches [the water]. The reason it is expressed as “the sprinkler” is to teach that they (the waters) do not defile unless they contain a sufficient amount for sprinkling.
One who touches, etc. shall remain unclean. °But his garments do not require ritual washing.
Anything which the unclean person touches. °[Which] this person who was defiled by a corpse [touches], shall become unclean.
And anyone touching. Him, °the one defiled by the corpse.

Shall be ritually unclean until evening. Here we learn that a corpse is a “forefather” of defilement, and whoever touches it is the “father” of defilement, and defiles another person. This is the explanation according to its plain meaning and its halachic ramifications. Now I have transcribed the Midrash Aggadah from R’ Moshe Hadarshan’s basic commentary, as follows:
They shall take to you. From their own. Just as they removed the golden rings, for the [golden] calf, from their own, so shall they bring this from their own as atonement.

A red cow. This is compared to the child of a maidservant who sullied the king’s palace. They said, “let the child’s mother come and wipe away the filth.” Similarly, °let the cow come and atone for the calf.
Red. To correspond with “If they [your sins] are as red as crimson. . .” Sin is described as red.
Perfect. To correspond with the Israelites, who were perfect, but then were blemished by it. This [offering] shall come and atone for them, and they will return to their perfection.
Upon which no yoke was laid. Just as they discarded the yoke of Heaven.

To Elozor the kohein. Just as they gathered against Aharon, the kohein, [and forced him] to construct the calf. And since Aharon constructed the calf, this service was not performed by him, for, the accuser cannot serve as the defender.
[He] shall burn the cow. Just as the calf was burned.

Cedar wood, hyssop, and crimson wool. These three species correspond with the three thousand men who perished because of the calf. The cedar is the loftiest of all trees, the hyssop the lowest of all, signifying that someone haughty who sinned with arrogance must humble himself like the hyssop and the worm to gain atonement.

A keepsake. Just as the transgression of the calf, which is preserved throughout the generations for punishment, as there is no reckoning which does not include an accounting for the calf, as it is said, “on the day of my reckoning, I will take into account . . . [the sin of the calf], And °just as the calf defiled everyone involved with it, so does the parah defile everyone involved with it. Just as they were purified with its ashes, as it is said, “he scattered it on the water, etc.” so “they shall take, for the one defiled, from the dust of the burnt sin-offering, [and place, upon it, spring water.]
The entire community. The entire, perfect community. °Those who were to die in the desert had already perished, and these were set apart to live.

Miriam died there. °Why is the portion concerning Miriam’s death adjacent to the portion of the parah adumah? To teach you that, °just as the sacrifices bring atonement, °so do the deaths of the righteous bring atonement.

Miriam died there. She, too, died °by the Divine kiss. °Why, then, is it not said, concerning her, “by the mouth of God”? Because this would be lacking in reverence toward the Supreme Being. Concerning Aharon, however, it is said, “by the mouth of God,” in “these are the journeys.”
The community had no water. From here [we derive] that all forty years they had °the well in Miriam’s merit.
Would that we had died. °We wish that we had died.
By our brothers’ death. °By our brothers’ death from the plague, as death from thirst is more dreadful.

By . . . death. This is a noun, like בְּמִיתַת אַחֵינוּ, “by our brother’s death.” But it is incorrect to interpret this as “when our brothers died,” for, if so, the vocalization should have been בִּגְו‍ֹעַ .
And their livestock. °From here [we derive] that the Holy One, Blessed is He, is solicitous of the Israelites’ property.
Assembled, etc. This is one of the places °where a small area held a large multitude.

Can we extract from this rock? °Because they did not recognize it, as the rock settled itself among the other rocks when the well departed. The Israelites were telling them, “What [difference] is it to you, from which rock you extract water for us”? This is why he addressed them as “rebels “—”insolents,” “fools” in Greek. Those who instruct their instructors. Can we extract water from this rock for which we were not commanded?

Twice. °Because at first, it only produced drops, since the Omnipresent had not commanded to strike it, but “speak to the rock.” They spoke to a different rock, but it did not produce. They said, “perhaps it must be struck, like the first one,” as it is said, “strike the rock.” Then they happened upon that rock and he struck it.

Because you did not believe in Me. °Scripture reveals that °if it had not been for this single sin, they would have entered the land, so that it would not be said of them: °”Like the transgressions of the rest of the generation of the desert, against whom it was decreed not to enter the land— so was the transgression of Moshe and Aharon.” But °was not [the transgression implied in the verse] “will sheep and cattle be slaughtered”? worse than this? Still, because it was said in private, Scripture was compassionate with him, but here, where it was in the presence of all of Israel, Scripture was not compassionate with him, because of the sanctification of the Name.

To sanctify me. For, if you had spoken to the rock and it had brought forth water, I would have been sanctified in the eyes of the community. They would have said: “Now this rock, which can neither speak nor hear, and does not require sustenance, fulfills the word of the Omnipresent. How much more should we do so.”
Therefore, you will not bring. This was said as an oath, like “Therefore, I swore to the house of Eili.” °He swore precipituously, so that they would not engage in lengthy prayer.

They are the waters of dispute. They are the ones mentioned elsewhere. Pharaoh’s astrologers saw them, [seeing] that the saviour of Israel would be smitten through water. Therefore, they decreed that “every boy who is born must be thrown into the river.”

He was sanctified through them. Since Moshe and Aharon died because of them. When the Holy One, Blessed is He, administers judgment against His holy ones, He is feared and sanctified by mankind. Similarly, it says, “You are awesome, God, from Your sanctuaries.” Similarly, it says, “I am sanctified by those close to Me.”

Your brother Yisroel. Why did Moshe see fit to mention brotherhood here? But he said to him, “We are brothers, children of Avrohom, to whom it was said, ‘[Know] . . . that your descendants will be strangers [in a land that is not theirs]’, and we were both responsible for fulfilling that obligation.”

You know of all the hardship. Therefore, your father parted from our father, as it is said, “he went to a land because of his brother Yaakov” — °because of the bill of debt incumbent upon them, he placed the burden on Yaakov.
[The Egyptians] mistreated us. °We endured much suffering.
And our forefathers. From here we derive °that the forefathers suffer in the grave when punishment is visited on Israel.
And He heard our voice. °Through the blessing bestowed by our forefather [Yitzchak], “the voice is the voice of Yaakov.” For, we cry out, and are answered.
An emissary. °This refers to Moshe. From here we derive that the prophets are called “emissaries” It also says, “they would insult the emissaries of God.”
Please let us to pass through your land. °You should not challenge the inheritance of the land of Israel, as you did not pay the debt. Do, for us, the small favor of passing through your land.

We will not drink well water. It should have said, “cistern water.” But this is what Moshe said: °”Although we have in our possession manna to eat and the well [water] to drink, we will not drink from it, but we will buy food and drink from you, for your benefit.” From here [we derive] that, although a guest has provisions in his possession, he should buy from the shopkeeper, in order to benefit his host.
We will travel by the king’s road. °We will muzzle our animals, so that they will not turn every which way to eat.

Lest I go out against you with the sword. You pride yourselves with the voice you inherited from your forefather, saying, “we cried out to God, and he heard our voice.” Well, I will go out against you °with my forefather’s legacy, “you shall live by your sword.”
It is just nothing. Nothing at all will harm you.
And a strong hand. °With our grandfather’s assurance, “but the hands are the hands of Eisav.”

The entire community. °All of them, perfect, ready to enter the land. Not one of them was among those included in the decree, for those who were to die in the wilderness, had perished. These were among those of whom Scripture states, “You are all living this day.”

Mount Hor (lit. the mountain of the mountain). A mountain on top of a mountain, like a small apple on top of a large apple. Although the cloud went before them to flatten the mountains, three mountains remained; Mount Sinai for the Torah, Mount Hor for Aharon’s burial, and Mount Nevo for Moshe’s burial,

At the border of the land of Edom. This teaches, that because they joined here in associating with the evil Eisav, a breach was made in their activities, and they lost this righteous man. Similarly, the prophet says to Yehoshafat, “when you joined with Achazyahu, God caused a breach in your activities.”
Take Aharon. With comforting words. Say to him, “How fortunate you are to see your crown handed over to your son— something which I do not merit.”

[His] vestments. °In the vestments of the kehunah Gedolah, °he dressed him, and then removed them from him, in order to place them on his son in his presence. °He said to him, “Enter the cave.” He entered. He saw a bed made ready and a candle burning. He said, “Go up on the bed.” He went up. “Extend your hands.” He extended them. “Close your mouth.” He closed it. “Shut your eyes.” He shut them. Moshe at once desired to die such a death. This is why it was said to him, “The way your brother Aharon died”— The death which you desired.
Moshe did. °Although the matter was difficult for him, he did not hesitate.

The entire community saw. °When they saw Moshe and Elozor descending, and Aharon did not desend, they said,”Where is Aharon”? He said to them, “He died.” They said, “Can it be that someone who stood up to the angel and stopped the plague is under the dominion of the angel of death”? Moshe immediately begged for mercy, and the ministering angels showed him to them, lying in the bed. They saw, and believed.
The entire house of Yisroel. Men and women, °because Aharon pursued peace, and instilled affection between antagonists, and between husband and wife.

That [Aharon] died. I say that anyone who translates [כִּי גָוַע as] דְּהָא מִית (“because [Aharon] died”), is mistaken, unless he also translates וַיִּרְאוּ as וְאִתְחֲזִיאוּ ([The community] “was exposed”). Since the Rabbis’ comment, that כִּי here is understood as “because,” is valid only according to the Midrashic comment that the clouds of glory departed, as R’ Abohu said, “do not read וַיִּרְאוּ (‘they [the community] saw,’), but וַיֵּרָאוּ, (‘they [the community] were exposed’).” According to this interpretation, דְּהָא (“because”), is the proper usage, since it clarifies what precedes it. Why were they exposed? Because Aharon died. However, according to Targum [Onkelos who translates] “the entire community saw,” “because” is not the proper usage, but “that,” from the אִי meaning, as we find אִם meaning “that.” As in, “that [I ask], why shouldn’t I be distressed”?Sf? and many clear usages in this sense, [like] “that his days are designated.”

The Canaanite heard. °He heard that Aharon died, and the clouds of glory departed, etc. as stated in Rosh Hashanah. Amelek was always a whip for disciplining Israel, prepared, at all times, to mete out punishment.

Who lived in the south. °This was Amalek, as it is said, “Amelek dwells in the southern part of the land.” They changed their language, and spoke in the Canaanite tongue, so that the Israelites would pray to the Holy One, Blessed is He, to deliver the Canaanites into their hands —but they were not Canaanites. The Israelites saw that they were dressed in Amalekite clothing, but spoke the Canaanite tongue. They said, “let us pray in a general way,” as it is said, “if you will deliver this people into my hand.”

By the route of the spies. The negev route traveled by the spies, as it is said, “they went up to the negev.” Another interpretation of דֶּרֶךְ הָאֲתָרִים ; the route of °the great pathfinder which traveled before them, as it is said, “[the Ark of the covenant of God traveled before them] three days’ journey, to seek out a resting place for them.”
He took from them a captive. It was only °one maidservant.
I shall consecrate. °I shall consecrate the spoils to heaven.
And he destroyed them. By execution.
And [consecrated] their cities. He consecrated them to heaven.

By the Reed Sea route. °Since Aharon had died, and this war fell upon them, they turned back to the Reed Sea route This was the route by which they had turned back when the decree of the spies was issued against them, as it is said, “travel into the desert, by the Reed Sea route.” Here, they turned back seven journeys, as it is said, “Bnei Yisroel journeyed from Be’eiros Bnei Yaakan to Moseirah. There, Aharon died.” Was it in Moseirah that Aharon died? Did he not die at Mount Hor? °But they returned there, and mourned and eulogized him as if he were in their presence. Go, examine the journeys, and you will find seven journeys from Moseirah to Mount Hor.
To circle around the land of Edom. Since they did not permit them to pass through their land.

Traveling was insufferable to the people (lit. “the people’s souls did not have the capacity for traveling”). Because of the rigors of travel, which were overly difficult for them. They said, “We were just close to entering the land, and we are turning back. This was how our fathers turned back, and they remained for thirty-eight years, until this day.” Therefore, the distress of traveling was insufferable. “Encrot lor” [“repulsive to them”, in old French]. But it would be improper to translate “the people experienced insufferability בַּדֶּרֶךְ, while traveling,” without specification of the cause of the insufferability; since, wherever one finds insufferability in Scripture, the cause is specified. For example, “they were insufferable to me.” And, for example, “Israel’s distress was insufferable to him.” Anything overly difficult for a person is depicted as קִצּוּר נֶפֶשׁ (lit. the incapacity of the soul), like a person beset by travail, who lacks the breadth of mind to accept that, and who does not have a place in his heart where the distress might reside. Now, the thing causing distress is depicted as looming large, since it is seems large and weighs heavily on the person. For example, “their souls loomed over me” —seemed large to me. [And, for example,] “Trapping me like a lion looms large.” The synopsis of the interpretation: Every statement expressing the soul’s incapacity for a thing means that it cannot tolerate it, for the mind cannot tolerate it.
Against God and Moshe. They equated the servant with his master.
Why did you bring us up. Both of them, equally.
We (our souls) are disgusted. This, too, denotes insufferability and disgust.

With this rotten bread. Because the manna was absorbed into the limbs, they called it rotten. They said, °“the manna will eventually swell in our stomachs. °Can anyone born of a woman take in [food] without excreting?
The consuming (lit. burning) snakes. °That consume a man with the venom in their fangs.

And they bit the people. Let the snake, who was smitten for speaking wickedly, come and punish those who spoke wickedly. Let the snake, for whom every type [of food] tastes the same, come and punish the ingrates, for whom one thing changed to numerous tastes.
Moshe prayed. From here we derive that someone from whom forgiveness is asked should not be mercilessly unpardoning.

Upon a banner. On a pole, called “perche” in old French. Similarly, “like a banner on the hill,” “I shall lift my banner,” “raise the banner.” °Because it is held high as a signal and as verification, it is called נֵס .
